speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, of course I am interested in Your Honour's ruling. I can see that Your Honour spent some time on
June 2, 1992

this, or at least Your Honour's assistants spent a great deal of time on it.
I noticed the usual summary was not read at the end. I can understand why. I do not think it could have been much shorter than the ruling itself.
Notwithstanding that, I wanted to comment, Sir, on the ruling, and specifically Motion No. 34, standing in the name of the hon. member for Papineau-Sain t-Mi-chel and the other similar motions concerning the effect of the referendum.
I realize that this motion was ruled out of order in committee and that that in itself might constitute grounds for Your Honour to rule it out of order here in the House, but I submit that the question of the effect of the referendum is fundamental to the consideration of this bill and it is one that needs to be addressed by this House and decided in this House.
The principal reason why the government has introduced this bill, and this reason has been the subject of debate both publicly and in this House over the last two or three years, was because of the failure of the Meech Lake Accord to allow for participation by Canadians in the writing of their own Constitution. The government engaged in a very extensive public relations program to involve Canadians in this process, starting with a royal commission, followed by extensive parliamentary hearings across the country on two occasions and has sought to involve Canadians in this process.
The purpose of this bill is to involve Canadians in the reform process and I note that the bill is entitled "an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada". I refer Your Honour to The Concise Oxford English Dictionary and its definition of the word "referendum". It is defined as:
- referring of political question to electorate for direct decision by
general vote; vote thus taken.
In other words the purpose of a referendum, what a referendum is by definition, is a decision by the electorate on a question referred to the electorate. That is what a referendum is. This bill establishes a referendum procedure according to the title of the bill. Yet in substance there is no binding effect to the vote that is taken by a referendum held under this bill.
The amendments seek to give some binding effect, however limited-and I submit it is quite limited, but it is
Government Orders
there-to the vote of the people in the referendum. It is a fundamental principle of a referendum that if you have one you are then bound by the result. It is a decision by the people, not a decision by somebody else. It is not for someone to interpret that decision and then make another decision. The decision is made by the people in the referendum.
What Motion No. 34, standing in the name of the hon. member for Papineau-Saint-Michel, says is that during the life of this Parliament, the Senate or the House of Commons shall not adopt any resolution authorizing a change in the Constitution where the amendment would be directly or indirectly contrary to the opinion expressed in this referendum by a majority of voters in Canada and in certain regions too. It deals with the majority vote of all Canadians.
It was suggested by the chairman of the committee, when he made a ruling on this issue in committee, that this imported some new notion on referendums into the bill. The argument was somehow made by the chairman in a way that frankly I could not understand that this made a change in the Canada Elections Act.
The referendum bill itself makes changes in the Canada Elections Act. It overrides it in certain particulars and it incorporates it by reference where it is silent on issues. The referendum is to be conducted in accordance with the practices set out in the Canada Elections Act. Clause 2(2) of the bill is the one that does it. It states:
Unless a contrary intention appears, words and expressions used
in this Act have the same meaning as in the Canada Elections Act.
There are other references in the bill that incorporate provisions of the Canada Elections Act.
With great respect, this amendment does not change in any way the effect of the Canada Elections Act. What will happen in this case is that results will be reported from the referendum vote on a constituency by constituency basis. The only reason that is being done is because the Canada Elections Act calls for reports on that basis and that is fine. In addition, there will be some additions made of those results on a constituency by constituency basis to provide for regional results to be released based on provincial results. I submit that it is done now anyway.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
We frequently see in the press the tabulated results of the election added up to show the percentage of the vote obtained by each party on a national basis and on a provincial basis. Sometimes we see it even on a regional basis. Certainly we see it frequently on a provincial and national basis.
This is not a case of changing the reporting mechanism. This is a case of changing the application of the results by adding them up and putting them out in a different tabulation. However they will still be reported on a constituency by constituency basis for what that is worth.
The motion is not intended to alter the way in which the referendum will be conducted. It simply means that when a referendum has been held, when the people of Canada have expressed their will and pleasure with respect to the question put to them, the answer to that question will bind this government.
It will prevent it from proceeding with the resolution during this Parliament to change the Constitution in a way that is contrary to the expressed wishes of the people. It does not force the government to do anything, it forces it to refrain from doing certain things. It does not make the referendum totally binding but it does place some stricture on the government's freedom to act, depending on the answer given to the question that is put to the people.
That is the expressed title of the bill. That is what the government says in the title of the bill it has set out to do. It shows the word referendum. It was not the case of the government not using the other word. If it is a consultative process, the word is plebiscite. It could have used that word in the title but it chose to use referendum.
Apparently there is some problem in moving an amendment to this bill which makes this into something close to a referendum. I do not understand the problem. To me it is a fundamental issue. It has been a major public issue in Canada for a long time. It needs to be debated on the floor of this House.
The chairman of the committee in making his decision after some objections from some of the members of the committee said: "Mr. Ouellet, I can appreciate the political importance of this. It is a question that probably should be decided in the House".
I quite agree with the chairman of the committee. I submit that this amendment is very important. It allows for a debate on an issue that needs to be decided here. If it is ruled out of order and cannot be even discussed, then I think we have missed the most important aspect of what this bill was intended to do and that is to provide the people of Canada with a direct voice in the establishment of their new Constitution.
The whole question is optional. The bill only permits a referendum to be held. I submit that the question of the effect of the referendum, once held, is vital to the bill. It is fundamental to the bill. The title brings it in. The first clause brings in that vital importance. If we cannot move amendments that give teeth to that importance, that gives strength to the expressed intention of the government in using the word referendum, then I submit that the debate on the bill lacks substance, lacks importance and fails to deal with the cardinal issue that the people expect to be able to deal with if the question is put to them. That is, their votes will count for something instead of being another public opinion poll.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with care to the comments of my hon. friend. I know it is going to be a very interesting day if this is the beginning of it.
Before responding, I take the liberty, Mr. Speaker, to express my thanks to you and the table officers who laboured through the night to group these amendments and to rule on them. It is one of the more complex chores you have had to face and I appreciate what has been done.
My friend from Kingston and the Islands makes several points, the first of which, of course, relates to the dictionary definition of referendum. I am sure we will hear from others of a more scholarly bent on that subject as the debate progresses.
Very briefly, Sir, the word referendum has become common usage in Canada for a non-binding vote. That may not be precisely correct as to dictionary definition but it has become an acceptable part of our practice.
The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands referred as well to the regional implications of this particular Motion No. 34 that is before us for discussion. The issue before us is twofold: First, whether or not it is appropriate to bind the interpretation of the results of
June 2, 1992

Government Orders
the referendum; and second, if that is the case, whether it is appropriate to group them according to regions.
With reference to the first point, it is true that conventional election results in this country are first tabulated poll by poll and then constituency by constituency. Thereafter, of course, they are tallied as to numbers over all throughout the country for purposes of determining who would form the government. That is the practice with a conventional election.
When we come to a referendum, there is really quite a variety of interpretations that could be put on the results, but none of them ought to, in my submission, be binding.
First of all, it is moral suasion we are looking for in terms of the result of any referendum. It is to guide those who must amend the Constitution of the country. Under the Constitution, of course, it is up to this House and the other place and the legislatures of the 10 provinces to pronounce themselves on any constitutional amendments. That is the way the Constitution is written and that is the way it will be until it is appropriately amended, if it ever is, in section 41 and the other amending sections.
The basic thrust of this motion would be to have the results interpreted as to the various regions of the country, being the Atlantic region or the provinces of Ontario and Quebec as individual regions and western and northern Canada as a further region. This sort of interpretation, I gather, flows out of the original concept of the make-up of the Senate but bears no relevancy to the interpretation of a referendum result. It is true that it was recommended by the committee which I had the privilege of co-chairing, but within hours that recommendation was tom to shreds by at least two provinces of our country and, therefore, is a non-starter.
In conclusion, I would just simply say that what this bill is designed to do is to provide some guidance to this House, to the government and to the Senate as to what changes are acceptable to the Canadian people. It can be interpreted in a variety of ways. I submit, Sir, no legislation should hamper the interpretation of the result.

Mr. Speaker, I too wish to rise on the interpretation. I recognize the hard work that you, the clerks and others have done on this. I have two concerns.
The first one is with regard to Motion No. 31, standing in my name, which has been ruled out of order in that it goes beyond the scope of the bill. One of the concerns I have with regard to Motion No. 31 is that it does not bind the government. We are not, in this motion, binding the government. What we are giving is a clause explaining how the government would interpret the results of the referendum vote. In interpreting the results, it would have to look at the results nation-wide. It would have to look at them in each of the regions of Canada. It would also have to consider the vote by aboriginal Canadians. There is a reason for that.
Again, I want to stress the fact that we are not, in Motion No. 31, saying that it would be binding upon the government. What we are saying is that this is how it interprets it. What we were told in the press release and in the statements by the government that accompanied the original introduction of this bill was that some time during the process the Prime Minister would tell us how he was going to interpret the results. I do not think that is good enough for Canadians. They have a right to know what the rules of the game are. What better place to set the rules than the House of Commons itself as part of the legislation from day one.
It is very important that no region feel left out. I, along with a number of members of this House, come from western Canada. I think a referendum which passed in other parts of Canada but was defeated in the west would create a very strong regional antagonism within this country. The same thing would be true if Atlantic Canada were the only region of the country that voted against a referendum, or the province of Quebec, or Ontario.
As I mentioned earlier, we have also included aboriginal Canadians because a lot of the clauses will deal with aboriginal Canadians. In fact, because the nature of this bill now is such that it is open-ended, it could be used for any number of referendums in the future. We could have a referendum which was solely on the topic of aboriginal rights, aboriginal self-government and there would be

no tally of how the aboriginal Canadians in this country voted.
I would argue that this clause should be allowed to remain in effect. I would also like to remind this House of what the government House leader said and that is that he would allow amendments that went beyond the normal scope of the bill.

Mr. Speaker, if you were to still rule that this was beyond the scope, I would then ask unanimous consent to have this motion called.
With regard to Motion No. 40, standing in my name as well, which calls for the government to establish funds to help those groups in Canada that do not have their own funding in order that they can participate in a referendum, I would make very similar arguments.
Unfortunately, one of the things this bill does is it lets money rule. If you have the money, you can spend up to $10 million and if that is not enough, you can form another group and it can spend another $10 million. If that is not enough-

I hesitate to interrupt the hon. member for Churchill. I am listening very carefully to what he has to say and I will hear a few more members of course. I also ask the hon. member for Churchill to complete his remarks in an appropriate way.
I do want to caution members about getting beyond the procedural position that I have to determine, getting into substantive debate on the principle of the bill or other principles that may of course be of great importance to members or to the House.
I am bound to make a procedural decision, and I know the hon. member for Churchill would want to assist me in that.

Mr. Speaker, I do not challenge your ruling and that is one of the difficulties.
I again refer to the government House leader's remarks. I will ask for unanimous consent later on for Motion No. 40 to be allowed to stand.
What I was trying to point out is that if we are going to set up a referendum system, especially with the very exorbitant limits that exist under this bill, certainly those groups, natives, women and others not having independent sources of funds should be able to receive some government funding. It will not necessarily be a large amount, but there should be some government funding so that they can have their input in a public debate.

Mr. Speaker, I will be brief because, quite frankly, I want to associate myself almost entirely with the remarks of the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands, and in part with the initial remarks of the hon. member for Churchill. Therefore, I do not have to repeat everything.
I appreciate the Speaker's problem. I certainly also want to add my thanks to that of the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader and to compliment the staff in the Speaker's office and yourself, Your Honour, in getting these 64 amendments before us in some sort of order, along with all the problems presented in trying to rationalize some of these difficult points.
I am not going to get into the merits of the issue involved but rather look right at your ruling, Mr. Speaker. In mentioning the difficulty you had with Motions Nos. 28, 29, 31, 32, 33 and 34, quoting from your ruling, you felt that it was dealing with the effect rather than the process. As the member for Kingston and the Islands
June 2, 1992

mentioned, there is absolutely nothing in those amendments that affect the process of taking the referendum.
I go back to the bill and clause 3 which sets out very clearly that "where the Governor in Council considers that it is in the public interest to obtain by means of a referendum". I am not going to get into the semantics of referendum or plebiscite, but the bill is a referendum. Other people will be speaking about it and there is an amendment on the floor by the hon. member for Etobicoke about changing the whole name of the bill from referendum to plebiscite which will be debated.
That is fine, but just clause 3 itself. As a parliamentarian with years of experience, some of us who have seen the fundamental clauses-clause 3 is the fundamental clause-what does that say? That says that "where there is a matter of public interest, the referendum is going to obtain the opinion of electors". It goes on: "and direct that the opinion of electors be obtained by putting the question to the electors of Canada or one or more provinces".
All the amendments questioned in that paragraph of your ruling do is in effect the reflection of the opinion of electors. In effect, clause 3 does not restrict how that opinion is to be tallied; it is open-ended. I submit, as others have submitted, the fact that the amendments we are discussing here on this point segregate the tally. It has not affected a thing with taking the vote, but it segregates the result. It is not of such injury to the fundamental principle of the bill that it should be a rule.
In the straight parliamentary sense, as the member for Kingston and the Islands says, this is a fundamental question of the whole process. Surely if the government does not like the segregation of the votes on clause 3, the opinion of the electors, if it does not like to segregate them by province or in the nature of the aboriginal Canadians, then the government very well will turn the amendment down and vote for the bill as is presently tabled in the House. That is the whole nature of the debate.
Government Orders
To preclude that fundamental issue for debate by a procedural ruling, which your Honour has the grace and humility to admit causes you some procedural difficulty, flies in the face of the whole reason why we are here, with respect, Mr. Speaker.
Let us have the debate on all the issues here. Certainly one of the fundamental issues, whether you call it a plebiscite or referendum or opinion poll, is you have a bill trying to get the opinion of the electors of Canada. Certainly if you get the opinion of the electors of Canada, it is a very legitimate question for this Parliament to decide should it be an opinion that binds or restricts some action of the government, or should it just be like a polling result. That is legitimate. Obviously members of Parliament should be entitled to decide.
I must say, since my amendment also shares the same extension as some others that you have called into question, of including the aboriginal Canadians as an aggregate, you could have-and there is nothing in this bill to prevent it, as the hon. member for Churchill pointed out-a specific and, quite frankly, I think a very legitimate question. Not getting into the other questions that are going to be decided here tonight, I think a very legitimate question is whether we should even have a Senate. Let us leave that for the moment. Let us talk about the aboriginal Canadians. There is a very legitimate question that Canadians have not decided.
Perhaps some of the political leaders in the closed isolation of conference halls from coast to coast have recommended in principle, with no legal language, in effect what the inherent right of self-government means. That is a very legitimate question by itself. How would we dare have that if, in effect, the tally of the aboriginal Canadians who were so directly involved were not tallied?
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate you giving me the time for this. I would submit in conclusion and summary that using, as I tried to do when I used to practise law, the very words of your opponent, and you are not the opponent, Mr. Speaker, but it is your judgment that we are having the opportunity and discretion through your

Government Orders
courtesy to comment on today because of the complexity of the issue, in effect using your own words, you say that it is dealing with the effect rather than the process.
I submit to you in the strongest terms that there is not one item of process affected in the amendments that you have challenged. Certainly if there was ever a reason to have the question before the House, this is a very proper question. Otherwise, there is an awful lot of wasted air that is going to be expressed on this whole issue.

Mr. Speaker, you mentioned this morning in your ruling that the amendments to the referendum bill relating to the double majority had caused you some procedural difficulty. You also said that, in fact, our motions were dealing with the effect rather than the process of referendums. You pointed out that they had been ruled out of order in the legislative committee.
If I remember correctly the operating rules for legislative committees, only members of the committee can table such amendments. I for one had drafted a number of amendments to the referendum bill and advised the legislative committee that I would be tabling the said amendments. I wanted the committee to be able to review them during its proceedings. However, because I was not a member of the committee, I was denied the right to formally table these amendments. That is when a member, the hon. member for Papineau-Saint-Michel, suggested tabling them on my behalf, which was ruled out of order.
That being said, why have a referendum act? The answer is because a constitutional impasse is likely. Why did the government go to the trouble of setting up the Beaudoin-Edwards committee on the constitutional amendment formula and the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee on the constitutional process as a whole? We are in an impasse and Quebec has not yet signed the constitutional changes brought forward by Mr. Trudeau and his government in 1982. The truth of the matter is we have been in an impasse ever since and the failure of Meech just made matters worse.
Today, our government realizes that, should we fail to agree in the next few weeks, a referendum will be held in
Quebec. There is a law in Quebec which says that a referendum could be held to ask people whether or not they want to pull out of Canada.
What are our responsibilities as parliamentarians and representatives of the Government of Canada? We must make some provisions to allow us, should the first ministers fail to agree, to ask the people of Canada to decide on the future of their country. It seems to me that Canadians should have their say before some premiers, because of their attitude, let the country split apart.
It is in this context that we are debating today a referendum bill which would, ultimately, give the Prime Minister the authority to go to the people if the provincial premiers fail to agree and refuse to present a resolution to their respective legislatures. All members in this House know it is only a consultation and cannot be binding on any government. The Canadian Constitution, since 1982, is very clear on the ways to change it, and referendums are not one of them.
If we have a Referendum Act with some rules, how is it going to work, to be perfectly fair from one end of the country to the other under our democratic system? It seems to me that it is fair and appropriate to ask the Speaker and this House that we indicate how the results will be interpreted.
In our history we had some instances, like the referendums of 1898 and 1942, where things were decided against the will of a province, Quebec, which voted no in both cases, since Parliament went along with the majority. Is it wise to fail again to provide for the effect of the referendum or how it must be interpreted?
I am going to give you an example. If we do not specify it, how are we going to tabulate the results? By province? Nationally? Who is going to decide? Let us assume a provincial premier had said: "I pledge that I will abide by the democratic decision of the people of my province." What would happen if, for example, the premier of Newfoundland had said that and people in that province would vote no? I will end on that.

I understand the strength of the hon. member's arguments, but again, I think that his intervention, which is very smart and relevant to the issue, probably does not help the Speaker to solve a procedural matter.
June 2, 1992

I certainly appreciate the hon. member's fervour, and sympathize with him to a certain extent, particularly considering the importance of this issue for all Canadians. Again, I would ask each hon. member to be a little careful, particularly during the intervention, because my ruling is about a procedural matter.
Maybe the hon. member could conclude.

Mr. Speaker, yes, indeed, Beauchesne's citation 698(1) reads as follows:
698. An amendment which is out of order on any of the following grounds cannot be put from the chair:
(1) An amendment is out of order if it is irrelevant to the bill, beyond its scope or governed by or dependent upon amendments already negatived.
In your arguments, Mr. Speaker, you mention it is beyond its scope. Indeed, a referendum bill that has only a consultative value has a lot of moral weight. It is exactly in such a context that the referendum per se is significant. It produces an impact because it sends a message from coast to coast on one particular aspect of the Constitution and of the future of our country.
Let me go back to that example; we could face the same impasse as we did with Meech. A national referendum without a regional majority means that, for example, if you take one province only, if a premier says he is bound by the opinion expressed by the people of that one province, Quebec's veto is out. It would be impossible to obtain simply because one province would have voted against it. I think we would be wise to learn from our past experience in order to avoid another Meech.
That was also the opinion of an all-party parliamentary committee, the Beaudoin-Edwards committee, when it said: "In our opinion, the federal authorities would be well advised to table draft referendum legislation before Parliament. Referenda would be optional. Authorities could resort to this mechanism when they deem it necessary. In our opinion, given the heterogeneous nature of the country, the draft legislation should stipulate a double majority: a national majority and a majority in each of the four regions. Referenda would not amend the Constitution of Canada and the results would carry some political but no legal weight. The results would not
Government Orders
be binding on the two levels of government, but would constitute an eloquent message".
It is in such a context, according to me, that we must establish the rules of interpretation of the referendum since they are part of the scope of the action we are about to take, if ever there is a constitutional impasse.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make a small contribution to this morning's procedural debate. Like all my colleagues, I heard your ruling. I must say it bothers me when you say: "These motions appear to be going beyond the scope of the bill in dealing with the effect rather than the process of referendums".
Mr. Speaker, I wish I could convince you these amendments go to the very core of the referendum exercise and make it possible to interprete and analyse the results. If the Canada Elections Act were to say: Elections are held but results are not discussed; it does not matter who is elected; and the results are binding on no one, you would have a problem. At this point, I believe what will not be discussed in this House is the very essence of the bill. Instead of getting down to the nitty gritty, we are going to have a debate on externals.
Obviously, talking about how enumerators are appointed has no connection with the actual scope of this bill. If there can be no debate on the significance of the results, I insist this will be a futile exercise, as futile as the attempts of the hon. member for Jonquiere to argue the benefits of a double majority. I have no desire to argue the merits of the amendments. The hon. member for Jonquiere should have made those points in his own caucus or mentioned them to his leader. As far as the substance of the various amendments is concerned, I believe that preventing debate on these issues means preventing the House from doing its job. Whether we are for or against amendments proposed by our colleague, the hon. member for Churchill, or other members, I think by trying to avoid this debate we will get the kind of situation we had during the conscription crisis, and God knows these walls must be haunted by the ghosts of that debate.
If we do not discuss the fundamental issue of what this exercise means or how it could interpreted, the legislation becomes meaningless. Mr. Speaker, without wishing

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
to cast doubts upon your wisdom, which is proverbial, I know that provided there is unanimous consent, you would agree to let us discuss substantive issues.
I will argue not the merits but the general substance of these amendments and I move for unanimous consent to agree to a real debate on these fundamental issues.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to join with other members who have thanked you and the officers of the House for having worked through the night to group these some 64 different amendments, bearing in mind that those are amendments that are in addition to the ones that we made last week in the legislative committee. It shows how much work is having to be done in such a short time as the result of important amendments being made to very important legislation for which we have waited quite a long time to have before the House.
So to you and others who have tried to bring order to this process, it is very helpful.
I would like to particularly direct comments to your interpretation with respect to Motions Nos. 28, 29, 31, 32, 33, and 34, all of which have to do with the effect of the referendum.
As you have explained to us, these amendments, all having essentially the same purpose, to make the results of the direct vote by the Canadian people have some consequences, give you procedural difficulty. As you state, these motions appear to be going beyond the scope of the bill in dealing with the effect rather than the process of referendums.
That of course is a problem created as the member for Kingston and the Islands, the member for Annapolis Valley-Hants, the members for Jonquiere and Churchill, and others have referred to with respect to the title of this bill and the word that appears throughout, mainly referendum.
The parliamentary secretary to the government House leader in addressing you on this point, Mr. Speaker, did draw attention to the fact as he stated it that the word referendum has come into common parlance or common usage in the country to mean any kind of direct vote.
Certainly at a couple of levels, at least in a couple of provinces, that is the case. The 1948 Referendum Act of Newfoundland contained nothing in its provisions that said what the results had to be, nothing to indicate that they would be binding or they would lead to anything, in fact is a plebiscite.
Indeed the excellent statute in the province of Quebec, la Loi sur les referendums, is a model of contemporary statute on this point but it, as well, uses the word "referendum" for what in the main are non-binding votes.
It is true that term has been used in a couple of provinces, but I submit to you for your consideration on this point the fact that it has never been confused in this place. The Parliament of Canada when passing the Prohibition Plebiscite Act, 1898, clearly envisaged the process and the consequences and used the word plebiscite.
Again, when Parliament passed the Dominion Plebiscite Act, 1942, it was the practice of Parliament to call the plebiscite by its name, plebiscite.
I submit that the procedural difficulties that you find flows from the ambiguity that has resulted with the government using the word referendum in an act which in substance only talks about a plebiscite.
I am not going to anticipate now the debate that will come later on my amendment No. 3, where I propose that we in fact change the title and the terms from referendum to plebiscite throughout which would certainly bring clarity if that is all that the substance of the bill is to be-

I wonder if I may be able to assist the hon. member and other hon. members.
I am going to hear the remainder of this intervention which is not only very interesting but is of historic significance from a member who, I think it is common knowledge in this House, has spent a great deal of time on it. One of my difficulties here is that an argument as to whether or not this should be called a referendum or a plebiscite does not help me very much. If a statute calls it a referendum, spells out what its effect is, that is the statute and that is the way it is passed that is, of course, what we would have to accept no matter whether the word is referendum or some other word.

That takes nothing away from the general debate as to how the word should be used, but the fact is that in the proposed law which we are debating, while the word referendum has been used it also, at least in the form as presented to the House at the moment, does tie that word with certain implications. All I am saying is that a debate on the definition of the two words does not get me very far ahead procedurally.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate your point and I understand your dilemma. Perhaps, your attention has been somewhat taken by another member. As I was saying on this very point, in addressing it, I did not look to anticipate now in addressing your ruling, Sir, the debate that will come later when we are dealing with Motion No. 3 standing in my name.
The point I was making and I will continue to conclude with is that the dilemma of a procedural nature that you face flows from where you say: "In my view, these proposals"-I am speaking of these six amendments-"exceed the principle established when the House gave second reading to the bill". It is from that interpretation that you invoke Beauchesne's citation 698(1). I think there is ambiguity as to what principle the House established in giving second reading. The bill that is before you and before this House at the present time uses the word referendum throughout.
On two previous occasions when Parliament enacted similar legislation in this area it chose, as a matter of principle, to call it plebiscite. There is ample Canadian evidence and historic fact in legislative history to show that when Parliament is dealing with a matter like this, words do have meaning and those are the meanings of the words.
Therefore, the interpretation you have given, which effectively rules out the possibility for debate here in the House of Commons as to the consequences of a process to involve the people in constitution making and constitution amending, I would invite you to reconsider, in light of the comments made by a number of members. If we cannot have this issue clearly addressed here on the floor of the House of Commons and resolved here, then where and when will it be resolved?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to raise another amendment you have ruled on and which I did not have a chance to deal with earlier. It is
Government Orders
my Motion No. 19. In your ruling you indicated it had been dealt with by the committee.
I will read my motion and I will also read the issue that was dealt with by the committee that I believe was substantially different and, therefore, my Motion No. 19 should be allowed to stand.
Motion No. 19 says it must be passed by an affirmative vote of 60 per cent of the members of the House, with or without amendments.
The motion that was defeated by the government in committee said: "Sixty per cent of the members of the House present and voting". My motion deliberately setting out a criteria which called for 60 per cent of the total membership of the House to vote for a referendum question, believing as I do that a referendum question should have the support of more than one political party in this House and there should be substantial support for that resolution before it is sent to the people of Canada. Therefore, I made the deliberate decision to make it 60 per cent of the total members of the House, not the motion that was defeated in committee which was 60 per cent of those who happened to be there when the vote takes place.

I want to thank all hon. members for their courtesy this morning in the interventions that they have made. Also, I ask the House's co-operation on future matters. Keep in mind that, as much as possible because of our consultative approaches, and trying to avoid having to argue these matters-I use the word argue in the best sense of that word-subsequent to the Speaker, the Chair is having to put the ruling to the House.
However, these matters in this particular case are, as I said at the beginning, brought to bear on us because of a great number of amendments that came in at the last minute. We did the best we could with them. I have indicated to the House that I shall take into account what has been presented to the Chair over the last hour and report back to the House as soon as possible.
I might say to the hon. member for Churchill that I will look particularly at the last point that he raised. I will think with great care on the first point that he raised as well.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know there has been some extensive

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
debate with regard to the procedural arguments of some of the amendments which did come in late last night and there was not an opportunity for consultations. I do not wish to be long in my intervention, but concerning Motion No. 34 by my colleague, Mr. Ouellet, in terms of the effect of a referendum, I realize there had been some discussion at the committee stage with regard to this kind of amendment. I believe that there has been, and I stand to be corrected, a tradition and an understanding within this House that even if the amendment were defeated in committee or ruled out of order based on procedural grounds, the Chair could allow this amendment to go forward and to be adjudicated by the members after having a reasonable debate within the House if it were found to be of an exceptional significance.
The regional majorities, as contained in that particular motion, are of exceptional significance and ought to have the opportunity to be debated and to be heard by all members from whatever political stripe, regardless of their political allegiance to party or to non-party.
It is my understanding that Motion No. 34 is very germane to this debate on allowing the Government of Canada the power to have a referendum in order to consult with the people of Canada. It would be a grave mistake on the part of the Chair if members of this House were not given a full opportunity in the debate to discuss the contents of that particular motion which we believe, both at this time as well as in subsequent years, could play a major role in constitutional renewal and, more important, in uniting Canadians under a federal system.
I thank the Chair for giving me this opportunity late in the morning to intervene on Motion No. 34. I would hope that the Chair would give this serious consideration in view of the exceptional significance that members in this House would associate with the regional majorities as contained in Motion No. 34.

We have been at this for a long time and given the circumstances members would probably agree that the Chair has been generous. I am going to reserve on these matters raised and I will try to come back to the House as soon as possible.
In the meantime I will propose Motion No. 1 to the House and I will make every effort to get back to be of assistance to members, taking into account the usual exigencies of debate.

Mr. Speaker, on a very short point of order. Several times it has been mentioned that these amendments came in in the last few minutes. All I am going to do is point out, as a point of order for the record, that they came in in the last few minutes and we all had to work overtime because of the invocation of that interesting rule 53(1) which cut off the normal time for preparing it.

The hon. member raises an interesting point. However, the rule was applied and the House did decide.
I do ask the indulgence of the House to allow me to retire and reserve and come back to the House as soon as I can.

Madam Speaker, on a point of order, nothing prevents me from turning to you since you are now replacing the Speaker. In view of the fact that the Speaker is reflecting on the amendments or suggestions made by hon. members about the different amendments that we could consider, could we obtain the consent of the House to await his answer so that we could debate this legislation knowing that we are speaking on the substance of the bill, not just on some procedural items? That is the point my hon. colleague from Shefford was raising a moment ago. That would have a major impact on the arguments we would like to bring forward in this rather important debate.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The Speaker has listened carefully, as you would surely agree, to all the arguments expressed by hon. members concerning certain clauses of the bill. He has decided that nothing prevents the House from debating other clauses at this point and suggested that we propose Motion No. 1 to the House, which I will call immediately.
June 2, 1992

Motion No. 1.
That Bill C-81 be amended by deleting the title and substituting
the following therefor:
'An act to provide for a referendum on the Constitution of Canada".
He said: Madam Speaker, I raise this motion right off the top because it speaks to the concern many Canadians have with the bill.
Originally the government came up with the idea of having a bill that would allow for referendums over a three-year period. Later on, when this matter went to committee, it was further amended to say that at the end of three years a committee of the House and perhaps of the Senate would look at this matter and decide if we are going to have referendums from then on.
A lot of people have been convinced that we need a referendum on this particular constitutional situation that we find ourselves in at the present time. A lot of people believe that across this country. One of the reasons that we have this legislation going through the House and through committee stage with a fair amount of haste is that people believe this legislation must be in place in case we have a referendum or a plebiscite, whatever we decide to call it at the end of the day, in order to deal with the constitutional situation we face at this time.
I can agree with those sentiments, that we do need legislation in case a referendum is to take place. I do not see why in this legislation, which is being rushed through and pre-empts the work of the Special Committee on Electoral Reform, should have a long life. Why should we say this legislation should be in place three years, six years, eight years, nine years ten years down the road?
If we need legislation to enable the Government of Canada and the Parliament of Canada to authorize the legislation this fall, let us pass legislation that does just that. Do not bind us for the next three, eight, nine ten years. The member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore has a private member's bill calling for enabling legislation for the purposes of referendums and plebiscites.
Government Orders
That is the way we should go. We should have actual legislation establishing referendums and plebiscites if that is what the House decides. To use a piece of legislation which was introduced to deal with one specific situation and make it wide open for the future is unfair.
Spending limits, which are being addressed in this bill, are being done quickly on the assumption that we have to have something that is charter proof in case we have a referendum this fall. Why should we pass legislation now that says these same rules and regulations will be in effect for the next three, four, five or who knows how many years in the future?
That is my concern. If we want legislation authorizing a referendum, that is what this legislation should do. Do not make it wide open. Do not use this as a back-door approach to allow all sorts of other constitutional referendums in the future. I would think that we are going against the whole idea of setting up a special committee to look at electoral reform if we do that.
We are saying that this House has to rush the legislation in because of something that we have to do for this fall, and at the same time we are saying that legislation will stay in place potentially forever and a day.
If the government really wants legislation and really wants rules that are there for this fall's legislation, this fall's potential referendum, that is what the legislation should do. That is not what is happening at the present time.
I fear that what the House passes in haste now will come back to haunt us two or three years down the road. We do not know what type of constitutional issues will be facing us two or three years down the road. We do not know what the government of the day may decide to take to the people in order to have a constitutional amendment.
We do know that the government in its wisdom or lack thereof set up these rules for this referendum. If it wants to set up rules for future referendums, that should be a different piece of legislation and it should act accordingly-

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am in sympathy with the gist of what the member for Churchill has said regarding the importance of having on the statute books of the country in general enabling legislation for direct voting, just as seven of the provinces have.
His amendment here is focusing on the fact that he wants to see this simply for a one-time vote and not be kind of an uncertain, open possibility for succession of direct votes on constitutional amendments.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
With respect to the last part of the member's comments to the House, I would invite his reconsideration of section 40 of the bill as it now reads. Following the amendments we made last week in legislative committee, which say this act comes into force and shall be reviewed and reported on, any recommended changes in the act by a committee of the House are designated for that purpose within three years from the act's coming into force.
It would be helpful for the members considering the remarks he has made to keep in mind that we now have created by the wording of section 40 the distinct reality that there will be, following a national plebiscite on the constitution, a parliamentary committee that will be struck to review the exercise and to make recommendations back here as to how and to what extent and what nature of changes ought to be made in the bill and in the act to make it perhaps the permanent legislation that he and I both have spoken in favour of.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very surprised that the hon. member for Churchill has moved this amendment.
I am surprised in one sense and, having witnessed the proceedings in the committee, I should not be. I thought the New Democratic Party would support referendums in principle and agree that referendums are very useful as means of consulting the people and giving the people an effective voice.
The public discussion that has taken place in Canada in the last period of time has focused on the need for the public to be directly involved in constitutional decision making.
We have had lots of consultation. Members of the New Democratic Party have served with our members and with members on the other side on parliamentary committees that have consulted extensively with Canadians. My over-all impression of the result of that consultation has been that Canadians say they want more voice in this.
We have announced that a referendum is a way to consult and allow Canadians a direct voice in decision making. We are prepared to push that as a means of ensuring that Canadians have a voice. We feel it is important that this be allowed for.
I do not know why the hon. member for Churchill would seek to restrict this procedure to a one time event. Perhaps the situation is that some members of Parliament are very distrustful of the general public and its ability to make rational decisions. I do not share that view. Members of this party generally do not share that view. We think there are issues the public is fully competent to make decisions on, major constitutional changes being one of them.
This bill does not require a referendum to be held. It is merely a machinery for one to be held if the government decides to proceed with a referendum. That is one of the criticisms we have made of this bill. One of the amendments we sought to introduce in committee was to force a referendum on this issue and that was defeated. That is one of the problems we face. We think it should be addressed in this bill, not something that is set up as a one time thing and then thrown out the window.
I hope the hon. member would reconsider his position. I hope members who are distrustful of the public and its ability to make intelligent and capable decisions would get over this mistrust and allow for this procedure to operate. It could be very effective. It allows for the participation the public is demanding in the Constitution amending process.
With regret I feel that I cannot support this amendment.

Madam Speaker, I too have concerns with the amendment, although when I first saw the bill I shared some of the views of the hon. member for Churchill.
*
Upon reflection and as the constitutional conferences have moved down to the stalemate they are presently in, I do see merit in the government having the machinery, as the member for Kingston and the Islands has said, to have a referendum process and maybe several referenda and/or single questions.
June 2, 1992

Without repeating everything that has already been said on setting up this whole machine, we know how difficult it is to get any bill through this House, especially a bill that touches so closely the very core of the country as a Constitution and a referendum or a plebiscite that is going to give an expression on the Constitution.
There is wisdom as a potential, as a piece of machinery that the government will have if the present stalemate is not resolved and a consensus comes up in a full-blown package from sea to sea. At the present time the odds on that are quite long. There will have to be decisions made.
I for one, as I have already expressed here yesterday on a procedural point, feel that the Canadian people can accept these questions. They all have been saturated with the issues for months now. The constitutional cavalcade has now come to a grinding halt. We are coming out of the conference rooms. It is time to let the people into the decision making.
I can see this bill giving potential power to the government to clarify some of the stumbling blocks that are perhaps presently preventing a consensus. Certainly a referendum on the very fact if we want a Senate and the very questionable referendum on if we want an undefined inherent right to aboriginal self-government are two things which we could not do with the amendment of my hon. friend for Churchill. It would be too restrictive. It would certainly be a waste of taxpayers' money to go through this procedure to set it up on one occasion and perhaps not have it there for other issues that might have to be resolved.
I too could not support this amendment. [Translation]

Madam Speaker, I understand the purpose of the hon. member who moved this motion when he explains that he would like to restrict the title of the bill to a single application or use. This bill is so unacceptable and the rules for public consultation that go with it are so undemocratic that it should be used at most only once and then erased from the statute books of the Parliament of Canada.
In fact, I do not think that the hon. member's purpose can be achieved through his motion, since in any case, this bill cannot be legitimized just by changing the title.
Government Orders
Changing the name will not change the unfairness and total unacceptabilify of this bill, which is illegitimate both in its principle and in its rules of operation. The principle of it is illegitimate for Quebec, of course. Many people do not know that for the past two years, a very broad movement has swept Quebec so that Quebecers can decide on the real issue which is at the heart of the political situation. The real issue which explains the political crisis that Canada is going through and is at its root is whether Quebec will be sovereign or not. That is the real question. People are trying to avoid it in all sorts of ways. Changing the title of a bill or restricting it to a single exercise will not hide reality.
The reality is that Quebec has determined, socially, politically and even judicially, to make a decision next October on its future sovereignty. The Quebec National Assembly even passed a law to this effect, which obliges the government to hold a referendum. Things are not going in a way that suggests that the Government of Quebec and Quebecers wanted to dodge the issue and avoid the deadline, as if they did not want to face reality and make a decision. On the contrary, everyone in Quebec is preparing for this referendum, which will be held under a Quebec law that has already existed for a dozen years. Bill 150, which the Quebec National Assembly passed in June 1991, requires holding the referendum soon.
It is obvious that this bill is meant to short-circuit the political decision that Quebec wants to make and substitute for the democratic rules of the Quebec Referendum Act totally unacceptable rules which are odious in many respects and which many members here, including government members, have denounced. Of course changing the title does nothing about that, especially since it would be strange to say using it only once is less serious than keeping it in the statutes of the Canadian Parliament, since it is to be used only once. What is it to be used for that one and only time? It is to be used to decide the future of Canada and the future of Quebec, as though that were not important, as though using this iniquitous, unacceptable law were futile and insignificant because it is for something as minor, trifling and unimportant as the future of a western country deciding Quebec's future.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
I submit this motion has no real significance and does not alter the very basis of the discussion that we are to have today. As far as we are concerned, of course we will vote against it.

Madam Speaker, I am looking at the title and the motion that has been brought forward, Motion No. 1, to change the title.
As far as I am concerned whether we have one referendum or many referendums it is a question of whether they are binding or not binding in the first place. Bill C-81 does not bind the Government of Canada. Therefore it is a motion that I cannot support.
On the other hand, I have been listening to the member for Lac-Saint-Jean and I agree with him that it is a fundamental problem. We have provinces that have referendum legislation. It has to be dealt with in that respect. The provinces have to decide what is good for them. Therefore from my point of view this bill is not good enough for Canada and it is not good enough for the provinces.

Madam Speaker, after having listened to the arguments of the member for Churchill, I have strong reservations about his amendment. Essentially, his argument is that this legislation is unfair, sometimes antidemocratic and we should not keep it. Let us do a job once, since we are dealing with the issue of Quebec and the Constitution, but after that, let us make sure that it disappears from the Canadian political scene.
In other words, the House is told to do a dirty job quickly and then forget about it as soon as possible. Consequently, I find the member's argument to be very very dangerous, especially when we are discussing a bill that would have consequences, at least political ones, on the fundamental law of the land, that is the Constitution.
If there is one element with which we have to be very cautious, vigilant and democratic, it is precisely the fundamental law of the land. Just think, any country could make small violations of the democratic principle regarding its Constitution and then claim to act fairly
regarding everything else. In fact, we are fundamentally undermining the credibility of the process.
As regards the other aspect, I believe that the member for Churchill should instead have proposed an amendment to change the name of this act and call it the Prime Minister's lifeline, or something similar. This would have been a much more appropriate title, because his proposal to call this legislation an act to provide for a referendum on the Constitution of Canada could, in my opinion, mislead Canadians. In fact, we all know that this referendum act has nothing to do with the Canadian Constitution.
We are all bound by the Constitution which provides that the only way that the Canadian Constitution can be amended is through resolutions before the legislated bodies. There is no other way. To make Canadians believe they are the ones who will amend the Constitution through a referendum is just a smoke screen.
Therefore, the foundation of this whole process is undermined because we know that it is strictly a futile political exercise from a constitutional point of view. More importantly it is a political rescue attempt for those who will want to use it and wrap themselves in the Canadian flag.
We should call a spade a spade. I sincerely regret we did not have more time to propose amendments, given the offhand manner used by the government to put an end to procedures. It is obvious that we could have proposed an amendment to rename the legislation an act to rescue the Prime Minister I believe this title would have been more appropriate and more eloquent.
Needless to say that when the member for Churchill asks us to support his amendment, he is not the least worried about the fact that this legislation has but one objective, namely to bypass the provincial premiers. It is fundamental in a federation such as ours; it is fundamental when you think about the initial agreement of this federation. This Parliament is the result of an agreement signed by two nations. Now the government wants to replace the agreement reached by those two nations with a kind of tyrannical power of the majority.
I am convinced our fathers never thought that one day this agreement between two nations, which was signed in good faith, would be replaced by a process such as this one. It is obvious the notion of equality for the various groups was very much in the mind of those who shaped our Constitution. It is obviously not acceptable to now try
June 2, 1992

to replace the clauses of this fundamental agreement by a phony referendum act.
I could also have suggested another title, which might be even more appropriate. That is an act on the big opinion poll. If you listen to the government spokespersons, they will tell you that this is only a consultative process. The one thing that those in this House who know something about polls can tell you is the fact that $100 million is a bit expensive for a big opinion poll.
Personally, I think that we could have passed a law providing for the hiring, for example, of Allan Gregg to conduct a national poll and find out what the population wants. This would have been a lot cheaper and I am convinced that the Prime Minister would have obtained all the results that he needs.
In this exercise aimed at trying to give a new definition to the act, the amendment proposed by the member for Churchill has little to do with reality. I would like to quote a colleague of the member for Churchill, who is supposedly a great champion of the principle according to which this legislation is unacceptable. I am talking about the member for Chambly. I will talk on his behalf since he is not taking part in this debate right now. He said that this exercise was an undemocratic fraud. I believe this could have made an interesting title, something like an act on the undemocratic fraud. Indeed, I think this could also have been a very appropriate title.
I think that would accurately describe the content of this bill, because any casual observer would notice something is not quite kosher here. Any democrat looking at this bill would say: "This legislation lets the government do just about anything". Any democrat who remembers what happened during the referendum in Quebec would say: "Good heavens, where is the yes committee and the no committee?" Questions, questions. The Chief Electoral Officer tells us there could be as many as 3,000 or 4,000 committees. There would be the yes, the no, the yes-no, the maybes, the maybe-yes, the maybe-nos. It is mind-boggling.
I am very concerned that no appropriate definition was found for this exercise. I am thinking of another title that

could have been used, like "an act to sabotage the Quebec process". I think that would have accurately described the purpose of this bill. After all, a title is supposed to indicate to the person who reads it what the bill is all about.
In other words, I would have voted for an amendment like "an act to sabotage the Quebec process" or "an act to kneecap Quebec". I think my colleagues and I would have voted for that kind of title.
We would have supported the title.

We would have voted for the title, obviously. I think the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean was right to intervene, because you cannot be too careful around here. With a title like that, it would have been obvious what this legislation is trying to do.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, as much as I believe in Murphy's law, I must oppose his amendment. The effect of this amendment would be to change the word referendums to a referendum in the title. While that may seem minor in its implications, it is major in its effect.
Bill C-81 before us is enabling legislation which would permit one or more federal referendums. I am not sure whether it is what his party has in mind, but what the hon. member has in mind is a one-time bill permitting only one referendum.
The proposed change is not in keeping with the intent of the bill. In practical terms, it is conceivable that a referendum would take place and that the results of that referendum and other consultations might indicate certain changes in the constitutional proposals were called for. Then it would be appropriate, obviously, to hold a further referendum and the effect of my friend's amendment would be to forestall that.
The alternative, of course, would be the necessity of passing another bill to enable another referendum to take place. It would not be appropriate, once having had one referendum not to have another if there were substantial changes to the proposals. For that reason, I recommend voting against the amendment, as I will do.

Madam Speaker, I just have a short response to the parliamentary secretary.
It seems to me from all the press clippings I have read and all the speeches I have heard from the Prime Minister and others, the intent was to have just one national referendum. All this motion does is make clear what the Prime Minister has been telling the people. There will be a national referendum and not two, three, four, five or six referendums, if a decision is made in this country to have a referendum in the first place.
If there is a positive decision to have a referendum, all the chats we have had and all the comments we have heard from the government across the way is to have that one referendum on the package which would take place right across the country. All this motion does is to make it very clear in the title of the bill that there shall be a referendum, singular, not referendums, plural.
The other point is that in the last 100 years in this country we have only had two national referendums. I would say, God help us if we need two in the next few months. I think the government should just put in the bill what it has always signalled to the country, that it is not planning on two or three referendums, it is planning
June 2, 1992

on one referendum if, indeed, there is even going to be one. That might not even happen.

Madam Speaker, we are getting into an endless discussion. The first motion presented by the hon. member for Churchill, which would change the title of the bill and call it "an act to provide for a referendum on the Constitution of Canada" instead of "referendums", suggests the member for Churchill considers this bill to be undemocratic, unacceptable and just a strong-arm job that this government wants to do on Quebec by passing this bill. It is meant to be used only once.
You know, when I was in business, I had a men's clothing store, among other things. We dressed people. It makes me think today that they are trying to dress the referendum bill up to make it look better, but without changing its content or substance.
I find it quite simply odious for this House of Commons to want to disguise a bill with subtle changes in an attempt to convince a majority that all is well here in Canada.
My greatest regret in all this is that except for those who are the true representatives of Quebec and its higher interests, namely the members of the Bloc Que-becois, ably led by the hon. member for Lac-Saint-Jean, except for them, this House would be prepared to pass an undemocratic, even outrageous referendum law with a minimum of consideration. Nevertheless, we know that the Government of Quebec used the Belanger-Cam-peau Commission to consult throughout Quebec and find out what Quebecers in all parts of that future country wanted. The Government of Quebec passed Bill 150, setting October 26,1992 as the deadline for Quebecers to be consulted on their political future, namely sovereignty.
Whether we are for renewed federalism or for Quebec sovereignty, I find it unfortunate today. I think the country's leaders should at least have the intellectual honesty to let this consultation proceed without being overshadowed. They should let it be fair and a benefit to all of society. That cannot happen on the basis of the way this discussion on Bill C-81 has begun.

Yesterday, we in the Bloc Quebecois opposed changing the filing deadlines. Madam Speaker, I came to the conclusion, while reading this bill before becoming aware of the amendment tabled by the hon. member from Churchill, that it was undemocratic and illegitimate. After taking note of the proposed amendment, this bill still appears undemocratic and illegitimate.
An impression of constant improvisation pervades the government's entire constitutional process. To fully understand both the bill and the amendment thereto, one must stand back and get a comprehensive view of the government's actions since the failure of the Meech Lake Accord. We saw the Spicer commission, or the Spicer circus as some editorial writers called it, seeking guidance, without exaggeration, even in day care centres. The Beaudoin-Edwards committee was followed by the Castonguay-Dobbie committee, and then by the Beau-doin-Dobbie committee, by a multitude of conferences attended by carefully selected participants, and later by special or standing committees, you name it. Finally this bill is illegitimate, because it has no legal basis. As an editorial writer suggested in Le Soleil, the referendum question could be: "do you like soft ice-cream?" This will bring us back, in the end, to the constitutional process which provides for ratification within three years, in each and every legislature; and some provinces-not only Quebec, but British Columbia also-are committed
to hold referendums. This bill is illegitimate because Quebec at least acted with rigour, with the Belanger-Campeau commission and Bill 150. Nobody has questioned the rigour, the seriousness, with which the Belanger-Campeau commission carried out its work. One thing that emerged clearly from the Meech process was that Quebecers alone will decide their future. This will no longer be decided in Newfoundland or in Manitoba.
Madam Deputy Speaker. Would the hon. member be kind enough to talk strictly about the object of the debate right now, namely the amendment proposed by the hon. member for Churchill? There will be other amendments to look at and we will have plenty of time to discuss the bill as a whole. I would appreciate it.

speechtext: I now recognize the hon. member for Laurier-Sainte-Marie.

Madam Speaker, if you check the transcripts you will certainly notice that I have been talking about the amendment since the beginning. I look at this amendment and I wonder about a referendum or referendums. Also, this legislation provides no spending limit other than $8.5 million per committee, but there can be an indefinite number of committees. Moreover, there is no framework legislation. Then this amendment goes precisely in that direction. This amendment says no act in practice, but a specific referendum.
In Quebec, there is what we call a framework legislation on referendums and the Bill 150 is based on that legislation. We have found a rigorous way of doing things. I would not support this amendment because the member should precisely require a framework legislation and see what the possibilities are. I imagine this amendment should be made with that objective in mind, but it is far from being the case. We should look at the possibili-

ties of holding referendums afterwards and passing laws that would precisely refer to a framework legislation.
Rather, the member says that there is no framework legislation, there is no need for one, but we can do a little special for Quebec. I believe that this is part of the hypocritical undemocratic tools that are often used in this whole constitutional process, whether it pleases some people or not. This is continually the case here.
I believe not only the amendment but the bill as a whole is unacceptable. It is somewhat futile and naive to act like little birds and at the same time be willing to swallow it all.
I thought that we would be the only ones to vote against this legislation and this amendment, but when I read the comments made by the member for Chambly, I realized that half of the NDP caucus was opposed to that bill. If the member for Chambly happens to vote in this House, he will hold the majority within his party. It will be 50 per cent plus 1.
The member also tells us that he would like a free vote so that members can vote according to their conscience. This implies that if it is not a free vote, it means some members vote unconsciously, unless the member no longer has a conscience, but this is what the member for Chambly said.
I believe this simple amendment changes absolutely nothing; it misses the issue, and it does not follow the democratic traditions regarding referendums. I might add those traditions are not followed in this House, based on the examples of 1898 and 1942. This is a far cry from democracy, as everyone has said, but I imagine that you do what you can when you do not have higher principles than that. However, there are other places in Canada, of which Quebec is still part, hopefully for as short a period as possible, where democratic procedures are followed. Besides, one of the government members used Quebec's referendum legislation to prepare a bill. I think we should take that into consideration. Our colleagues from Quebec, those who do not belong to the Bloc Quebecois but still seem to have roots in Quebec, should turn to the Quebec referendum legislation for inspiration. It is a parent legislation and not an occasional act, as the amendment seems to indicate.
Government Orders
I do not see why they want to change the title. There is more than meets the eye here, since they are really saying we do not need a parent legislation, only a special one, a quickie for Quebec. That is exactly what they are saying and that is precisely what they are suggesting. We will play a dirty trick on them, we will block the whole process in Quebec, and then we will crow, unanimously, over our victory in a huge poll prearranged for a federal election. The object, of course, is not to use one or many referendums to save Canada and to solve the Quebec issue. It is to save the Conservatives' skin, to save the Prime Minister. That is how things stand since Meech.
Ever since Meech, we have been going round in circles, creating commissions like the last one, the Beaudoin-Dobbie committee. No later than yesterday, Senator Beaudoin was saying that the Senate is unacceptable. He was the one chairing that funny committee, right? But as we often say in Quebec, even though we are laughing, it is not funny.
Unfortunately, this is where things stand right now. They are trying to amend this shameful legislation, to give it a new flavour, by saying there will not be bills on referendums but one bill on a referendum. We do not care a hoot about the rest of the principles. I will be voting against this amendment.

Madam Speaker, I wish to support my Bloc Quebecois colleagues and some NDP members who are fully opposed to the proposed amendment.
As my colleague from Laurier-Sainte-Marie pointed out, the sole purpose of this amendment is to change the bill's title, but a very meaningful title nevertheless. The debate on Motion No. 1 must address the following question: do we want referendum framework legislation or only a referendum which can be carried out quickly to avoid getting our hands too dirty, while still allowing us, afterwards, to claim that we are great democrats and that we always abide by the great principles of democracy.
This amendment is dangerous, because it will make this is a specific action against a highly democratic and well thought-out process on the part of Quebec. This will, to begin with, hamper that process. Why not proceed as in any other democracy and, more specifically, as in England where a referendum was held to decide whether or not to join the Common Market. How did it

proceed? It adopted a referendum framework bill and then adapted it to the referendum on Britain's entry into the Common Market.
The initial preoccupation was to create a democratic process, one which would eliminate any doubt, inspired as it is by the same principles as the Quebec Referendum Act which restricts expenditures, provides for yes and no umbrella groups, and provides both sides with start-up funds. The country gave itself a referendum framework or legislation. Legislation inspires respect; it must be above suspicion and reflect, not the petty intentions of a government which is losing momentum, but principles emerging, in a parliamentary context, from our democratic past. In this sense, the British parliamentary system provided a model for the whole world, and justly so, as to the validity of and the principles which guide each debate and lead to a democratic vote, a vote on principles, often on framework legislation. Based on these principles, a specific action plan will be defined.
This amendment is contrary to time-honoured principles of the British parliamentary system in that its purpose is not to provide parent legislation to give everyone a chance to express views and serve democracy well. Heaven forbid. A little referendum would be much too embarrassing, a little referendum we are ashamed of and do not want to discuss.
As a matter of fact, this referendum has even been announced in the last throne speech. The same thing will happen when election time comes. "What did you do, Conservatives members from Quebec when the debate was held, will we ask?" They will answer: "We were hiding." Then, people will answer back: "You can go and hide forever now." Their voters will hide them forever in a comer of their ridings because they did not stand up for the fundamental principle of democracy that there should be an omnibus bill on referenda instead of this mere scrap of legislation to deal with a temporary situation. In so doing, we feel ashamed because we know that we are interfering with the very principles that have lead to the careful consideration of the question by the Belanger-Campeau commission during a year and a half in Quebec as well as with Bill 150 which will continue to guide our reflection in a very democratic context, under the "yes" or the "no" banner, with a ceiling on expenditures and restrictions on the number of speeches.
Instead of that, with this amendment here, we will put restrictions on this referendum just for the sake of pulling a fast one on Quebec and on democracy at the same time. We are spoiling and bringing shame upon this honourable institution and the entire British parliamentary system at the same time.

did not speak up against such interference, a real hold-up on democracy.
