Madam Speaker, today we are discussing a very important amendment to the referendum bill. We have to decide if we are going to call the bill an act to provide for a referendum on the Constitution of Canada or an act to provide for referen-dums on the Constitution of Canada. In any case, we cannot accept a bill which simply tries to ignore the will of Quebecers. We also realize that we are going through the same experience as in 1978, when the Trudeau government tabled Bill C-9 under almost the same circumstances as today. That was when Quebec decided to pass its own referendum bill. At that time, the federal government, which was Liberal, decided to table its bill which, ultimately, did not pass third reading stage, since an election was called before that. We can see full well the context is the same today. People in Ottawa are annoyed because there will be a referendum in Quebec. The pressure is mounting and the federal government finally decides to short-circuit what could happen in Quebec.
The Conservative government, which decided to table this bill, has no longer any legitimacy, as we know. We only have to look at the recent polls to fully realize why we have this bill. Yesterday, a Gallup poll mentioned leaders' popularity, and again, we saw that the Prime Minister's popularity had dropped to 16 per cent.

Madam Speaker, I feel my remarks are quite in order. They relate directly to this amendment, and when we deal with an amendment, references to the legislation are inevitable.
I am sorry, but if you ask me to speak to an amendment without referring to the legislation, I can do so only with great difficulty. When I speak to an amendment I also speak to the legislation, and I point out what made the Tory government propose this legislation. That, to my mind, is part of the debate.
If we cannot say what motivated the Tory government to table a referendum legislation, I think we are missing the point altogether.
Absolutely.

For my part, I think I have to deal with the substance of this legislation. The reason we have a referendum bill at this time is that the Tory government is at 16 per cent in the polls, and that is exactly why this legislation is now on the table.
We are now debating an amendment to change the title of the legislation, so that it provides for a referendum instead of referendums, but that is quite inappropriate. Anyway, what difference does it make if the legislation provides for a referendum instead of referendums? On that account, I am entitled to discuss this motion and I am entitled also to discuss the substance of this legislation. I cannot discuss one without the other. I am very sorry, but that is the way I see things. That is what I wished to explain.
I will go on by saying that we are now at a time where, rather than having to discuss a referendum bill, we should have an election. Normally, after four years, a government calls an election instead of proposing referendum legislation.
That is, in my view, the heart of the matter and I cannot ignore it. The government tries to bypass the issue, but it can fool no one, and it is my duty to denounce it.
I also wanted to stress that when those members brought in this referendum legislation, the government was not concerned with the interests of Quebecers, but only concerned with staying in power. It should be understood that those are the motives behind this legislation, and as a member of the Bloc, it is my duty today to condemn those motives.
June 2, 1992

Since we are discussing the title of the bill, I have a suggestion. I hope I will not be told I am off topic, because I would like to suggest the following title: "the cowards at Quebec's expense act". I think it would be an appropriate title. They are cowards because they are afraid to call an election and "at Quebec's expense" means they do not want Quebec to have its own referendum. They want to short circuit the process. I think that would be an appropriate title.
I could suggest another one: "An Act concerning an endangered party and artificial support systems to keep it alive".
Not bad.

I think that would also be a good title to discuss. Of course, because of pressure to speed up the debate, there was not enough time to submit these amendments to the Chair, but I think they would have been very appropriate. If I had to choose, which would not be easy-I would take the cowards-more appropriate, considering the kind of government we have today.
In concluding, I want to say I will certainly vote against this amendment and against the bill. I say this because I think Tory members from Quebec should do the same. They should rise in the House and tell us what they think about this amendment-
They are hiding.
They do not think they are hiding.

-what they think about the title and what they think about the bill. You say they do not think. Well, I certainly would not have dared to go that far. I would like to hear from them and I see the hon. member for Beauhamois-Salaberry. Perhaps he could rise in the House and tell us what he thinks of the referendum bill and this amendment.
To confirm what I have been saying, I would like to quote an article from the Journal de Chicoutimi which says, in referring to the hon. member for Jonquiere: "-
Government Orders
it is clear that when Jean-Pierre Blackburn bravely criticizes his government's policies, speaking up for Quebec's interests, Quebec is really the last of his concerns." Incidentally, we read this in a daily newspaper published in the riding of the hon. member for Jonquiere. I admit I would not have felt very flattered if the same kind of article had appeared in my own riding, but I imagine the hon. member will respond in kind to this journalist who did not seem to appreciate him.
In other words, I expected that. If the hon. member for Jonquiere wishes to speak, I would ask him to rise from his seat, since he seems to want the floor. My comments seem to have inspired him. If he really wants to speak, I suggest that he rise in the House, and we will be delighted to listen.
I hope he will speak to the amendment.

Yes, of course. We would like to hear him talk about the amendment, because this is so important. We know he could manage to be more relevant than the Bloc, because he has been a long-time member of various committees. I think he sat on all of them in turn. But finally, it would be-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I am sorry to interrupt the hon. member but her time has now expired.

Madam Speaker, on a point of order, perhaps you will allow me to tell the people who are making these comments that they had as much time as I did to table amendments to Bill C-81. They had just as much time, and furthermore, some of them were present at the legislative committee.
As far as defending the interests of Quebec is concerned, I think they should have-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: This is debate. I am sorry but I must interrupt the hon. member.

Madam Speaker, I understand why the hon. member for Churchill tabled an amendment to remind the government that the referendum bill should apply only to one referendum. I under-

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
stand because during the past two years, we have seen any number of committees travelling across Canada.
There was the Spicer commission which sort of failed. The member for Jonquiere, who followed the exercise rather closely, mentioned this commission tabled a rather meaningless report. In any case, it would have been very hard for the government to hold a referendum based on such a report. I imagine that it would have been the first of a series of referendums. The government tables a bill on referendums probably because it intends to hold several of those.
I understand the member for Churchill is worried the government will not make a decision based on its past record. We know in the last ten years or so, and especially in the last two years, the government and the three main political parties in Canada cannot agree on how to renew this beautiful country, as they say.
There was the Beaudoin-Edwards committee, the Castonguay-Dobbie committee, which also failed and became the Beaudoin-Dobbie, and then there was the weekend committee. Each of those committees tabled reports that most of the time contradicted each other. Let us now look at what has been taking place in the last two or three months, with those 400 people going from one city to the next all across Canada. This is of course very good business for those hotels and cities, but it seems strange that a government with a $430 billion accumulated debt and a deficit of $32 billion this year can travel across the country and pay for the expenses, hotels and meals of 400 people, in order to discuss things that we already know.
We already know what Quebec wants, because Quebec has performed one of the most rigorous exercises in the history of Canada, namely the Belanger-Campeau commission whose co-chairman, Mr. Campeau, is now going to travel through the province to gather business people and promote the sovereignty of Quebec. There was the Belanger-Campeau commission, which was an unprecedented exercise. Six hundred briefs were received by the commission and at the same time, fifty-five experts did parallel studies. They demonstrated that it was necessary for Quebec to patriate almost every power in order to develop properly. English Canada is aware of this rigorous exercise that took place in Quebec. Why continue to travel across Canada in order to find out the opinion of
Quebecers and of the rest of the country when we already know the answers?
Now we are undertaking yet another exercise called a referendum. Apparently, the Canadian government will spend more than $100 million to hold this non-binding referendum. All they want is to once again ask the Canadian population for its opinion. We have known that opinion for ten years already. Each year, month after month, the government says that it wants to know what Canadians think and what kind of Canada we should have. Once again, this government wants to ask Canadians that same question, this time through a referendum. We know very well this referendum is not legitimate. It will not change the Constitution because it has no legal value. We know that to make constitutional amendments, you need the approval of at least seven provinces representing at least 50 per cent of the population. Such changes must be ratified by the provincial governments.
This referendum is strictly a consultative referendum. The government will bother the Canadian population. It will spend at least another $100 million of taxpayers money while it is already in debt, to ask Canadians what they think of Canada. We need only ask the companies that specialize in polling. It would cost us barely $100,000 and we would have exactly the same results, without disturbing the people.
Within 2 per cent.

With proper polling, within 1 per cent.
I very well understand the hon. member for Churchill saying there could be only one referendum, because the government could also start another exercise over again; committee after committee, another Spicer commission, another Beaudoin-Dobbie, Castonguay-Dobbie, Beaudoin-Dobbie again, weekend committees and referendums and spend ten years talking and talking to come up in the end with what we already know now.
Madam Speaker, why would we continue with these exercises-
Futile exercises.

-that are futile and hurt the economy of Canada and especially Quebec? We are here to defend Quebec's interests. This uncertainty makes
June 2, 1992

our Quebec premier uncertain himself. He goes back and forth because he does not know what the federal government will do. He is acting the same way, in order to have it both ways.
We in the Bloc Quebecois and I especially are against a referendum. The hon. member for Jonquiere just said we too should have proposed amendments. I want to tell him we do not want amendments; we do not want a referendum, because we are fed up with spending Quebecers' money. We give the federal government $24.5 billion a year and it wastes our money. We will not let Canadians waste another $25 million on a referendum, or let Quebecers give the federal government another $25 million to hold a phony referendum, a sort of opinion poll, when we know that we could spend $25,000 in Quebec to do exactly the same thing and come up with the same results.
We are against this referendum. We find it outrageous and we are here to represent Quebec's interests. We say to Quebecers: Participate, but refuse to answers the false questions presented by this irresponsible government that does not want to defend the national interest. It says it is the country's future, but it does not want to defend the national interest. It wants to defend its own partisan interests.
That is what it wants to do. it wants to score points. The federal Liberal Party does the same thing. It is trying to score points, and so is the NDP. We do not want to score points. We want Quebecers to-
We want to get out of here.

-get out of all these endless discussions. We absolutely want Quebecers to be able one day to develop as they should and create the richest country in North America. That is what we want for Quebecers. We are tired of all this foolishness and nonsense.
I am against this referendum and I will work day and night if necessary to tell Quebecers not to get involved in it and waste our time and money. All we want is to build a prosperous Quebec to have a better quality of life. That is what we want.

Madam Speaker, you will note that the Bloc Quebecois members regularly have the floor this morning. Since it is often difficult to
Government Orders
do so when one wants to speak on bills, one can wonder. This morning, as if by magic, we all get to speak. We can all speak to an amendment because our colleagues across the way are silent. Except for the member for Beauhamois-Salaberry, who regularly attempts to intervene, they do not consider this bill sufficiently important.
He only speaks while sitting.
Ah, he has risen.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Privy Council
speechtext: Some say that I never speak, Madam Speaker. I would simply like to state that we are debating clause 1 and that I support the title.
Is the hon. member for Beauhamois-Salaberry asking for several referen-dums? Is that why he supports the title?
He supports the title of parliamentary secretary.

I think, Madam Speaker, we have reached the bottom, given the situation in Quebec, the context in which we have to make our decision, and the constitutional discussions where, for two years now, we have known that the government had promised to submit acceptable offers to Quebec. Now, they come up with a bill to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada, and the hon. member for Beauhamois-Salaberry tells us he supports the title.
Even one referendum in unacceptable, but now our colleague, a former nationalist, decides that, as far as he is concerned, the title should say referendums. Does the government want to hold one referendum after another, like it created one commission and one committee after another? I want to tell my hon. colleague that, unfortunately, many of those commissions and committees had all the time they needed in the last several months. Now time is running out. Soon there will be a deadline: the federal elections.
I do not quite understand the need to hold several referendums, costing $100 million in public money in organization expenses only, after we have had the Spicer commission. I see the hon. member for Edmonton Southwest and I want to mention the Beaudoin-Edwards commission, which all cost millions and millions of dollars. Now, we have the Constitutional caravan made up of 400 people travelling throughout Canada, from city

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
to city. They stop somewhere, go round in circles until they get tired, or one of them looks about ready to explode; that is when they decide it is time to move on. There, everything stopped. The minister in charge announced that great progress had been accomplished. The caravan left for another town, with 400 persons moving again. There it started all over, round and round and round. We were told there was progress. It seems we made progress on the native people issue.
It is really incredible that the federal government would accept to recognize the inherent right of native people and would declare that the courts would define that right in three years if no agreement is reached before that. On the other hand, that same government, that same constitutional committee would refuse, in the case to allow the distinct society clause to be used in the interpretation of the rights and powers which already exist in the Constitution. It is quite extraordinary. Now some members from Quebec want to support a bill on referendums in Canada which aims evidently at delaying the schedule because we know quite well this referendum will be unacceptable for the population of Quebec. The reply to this attempt to bypass the process already going on in Quebec will be a definite no.
The government had all the time it needed and the provinces had all the time required and they spent fortunes. It is easy to understand the cost of federalism. In Quebec, we had the Belanger-Campeau commission which was very interesting, very relevant and entirely televised and the whole process cost approximately $5 million.
The cost of the constitutional commissions, committees and caravan greatly exceeds $100 million already. Of this, 23 per cent comes from our taxes. In reality it comes from borrowed money, of which 23 per cent is borrowed on our behalf because the deficit continues to increase.
That is very frustrating. The Government continues to spend our money, to borrow on our behalf, in order to finance a constitutional caravan which leads nowhere and does not meet its deadlines.
What is still more frustrating is to have to listen, every night on the National, as they repeat that no progress has been accomplished, that they are happy or unhappy, that they have made great progress but not enough.
Worse still is the use of borrowed funds to pay for commercials, even during the hockey play-offs. These broadcast slots, used for subliminal publicity boasting of Canada's greatness, cost a bundle. It is shameful.
It is beautiful.
It is shameful. The member for Jonquiere finds it beautiful. That is extraordinary.
Supposedly a great nationalist.

Yes, a great nationalist, even in his own riding.
I have here an editorial which appeared in his riding, and I quote: "Should one take these negative comments seriously-"

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Would the hon. member kindly restrain himself to the amendment before the House?
Say something about the editorial's title.

Madam Speaker, this article deals precisely with the referendum. It says how seriously we must address the issue. There is nothing unusual about an editorial writer questioning the seriousness of some of the comments members can make, particularly when they show up regularly on the news because they slightly disagree, or so it seems, with their government. For months now, those people have been making promises.
Not so long ago, just a few months ago, the idea of holding a referendum was considered unacceptable by them. Never was the federal government to hold a referendum in Quebec. That is what the Prime Minister himself was telling us not so long ago.
And the minister of state.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Seniors); Minister of State (Employment and Immigration)
speechtext: It is still unacceptable.
The Minister of State just said it is still unacceptable. Well, at one point, all those assertions will have to-
Madam Speaker, on a point of order, I do not know if this will show up in Hansard, but I did hear the minister say that it is still unacceptable. Did she really say that?

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
This is not a point of order, as the hon. member knows.
The hon. member for Rosemont still has about 40 seconds.
Forty-two!

Madam Speaker, I think our House leader asked a pertinent question, and I can confirm that the Minister of State for Employment and Immigration indeed repeated that a referendum would be totally unacceptable, and we fully agree with that.
The government will soon have to take action to match its words. All Quebecers are wondering about it. They are wondering about the hon. member for Jonquiere in his region, as is to be expected. It is right in the heart of the debate.
When we criticize or say that a referendum is unacceptable and we are presented with a referendum bill that refers to referendums-

speechtext: I am sorry to have to interrupt the hon. member. His time is up.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to intervene in the debate now to bring up something quite basic.
The bill before us today allows the government to consult the people, if it sees fit to do so, as the title clearly says. It is an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada.
I am very surprised that our colleagues in the Bloc Quebecois did not even take the trouble to read clause 3 of the bill, which says very clearly the government can hold referendums or a referendum throughout the country or in one or more provinces.
Obviously, the proposed amendment that would limit the government's ability to consult all Canadians is certainly not one that we will support. We will not support it because it is obvious that the Government of

Canada has the right to consult Canadians, just as the Government of Quebec has a referendum law and no one objects to the Government of Quebec consulting its people. The same thing happens in British Columbia. The Legislative Assembly of British Columbia passed a bill allowing the government of that province to hold a referendum and consult the people.
I wonder what kind of hypocrisy this is, this show that the Bloc Quebecois members are putting on to have us believe they are defending democracy.

Madam Speaker, the hon. member will be surprised to learn that we share his position and that we are also against the amendment. I am sure that using a word like hypocrisy is not very appropriate. You know the Speaker already asked other hon. members to withdraw such an unparliamentary word. My ears are shocked to hear words like those. I suppose yours are too.

The Chair is really concerned about the hon. member's ears. Maybe the hon. member would want to think about mine, because I have been here since 10 o'clock this morning.
The hon. member for Papineau-Saint-Michel may rise again.

Madam Speaker, clearly the Canadian government by providing for a means to consult the people on constitutional amendments, if it is deemed necessary, is doing something most democratic and most legitimate.
The Liberal Party of Canada and its leader have been demanding such a law for months and months. In this way, the government of Canada will be able to consult the people across Canada, or in some provinces only, if they would rather have it done by the federal government instead of the provincial government.
I believe that the principle of a law to permit the people to vote on major constitutional amendments is totally democratic and should be accepted by all members in this House.
If some hon. members have concerns about some aspects of the bill, I agree that we should discuss them, but systematic opposition, of the kind we have seen this morning from members of the Bloc Quebecois, to a Canadian referendum on constitutional proposals is out

June 2, 1992
of place and out of order in the context of the constitutional negotiations presently in progress.
This is a wrong debate to question the advisability of letting the government of Canada consult the people.
Obviously, the Bloc Quebecois is very concerned there might be a referendum on constitutional proposals which might be accepted by the people of Quebec. This would be the end of their role in Parliament. From that point of view I am not surprised they should object so strenuously to this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to bring to your attention and through you, to all Canadians, a memorable event that took place in Thunder Bay last Sunday.
Approximately two years ago, St. Anthony's Church was completely destroyed by fire. Last Sunday, the new St. Anthony's Church was dedicated by Bishop John O'Mara.
For over 75 years, St. Anthony's served as a centre of religious and cultural heritage for Italians who chose Canada and made it their home. More recently, it has embraced the Portuguese community who have also chosen Canada as their new home.
The community of St. Anthony's is an example that should guide us all in the faith for the future of Canadians, the hope for a united Canada and a love that we all share for Canada.
I would like to thank Father Ermete Nazzani, who gave us his leadership, Father Umberto Rizzi, who continues to give us his guidance, and Father Riccardo Bezzegato, who is now the pastor. They all deserve our gratitude for continuing to provide for the cultural and spiritual needs of our community.

GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in Quebec City yesterday the Secretary-General of GATT, Arthur Dunkel, left the clear impression that there is hope for the supply management system in Canada. His words gave Canada's supply management agencies cause for believing there is a window of opportunity to continue seeking a clarification and strengthening of article XI so as to maintain our marketing system.
While Mr. Dunkel gave no firm commitment, he did
suggest there was hope when he said that marketing
June 2, 1992

boards were still a question mark and that those involved must carefully examine how supply management functions and how this system can co-exist within a new GATT agreement.
The federal government must stay the course to ensure that the greatest possible pressure is applied to world leaders and key players in these negotiations. Canada cannot afford to lose its supply management system. Thousands of farm families, rural communities and agrifood industry workers depend on the system which provides the steady supply of good, wholesome dairy and poultry products for Canadian consumers.
I call on the Prime Minister and his government to see these negotiations through to the end so as to preserve this most stable part of our Canadian agricultural system.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday marked the official opening of yet another Atlantic salmon season in many Canadian rivers.
The salmon has become a challenging symbol for our society in two important ways.
First, its very survival is a reflection of our commitment to conservation. Once a resource that was available in abundance, the salmon is now a fragile species that tests our environmental will and discipline to the extreme.
Second, the salmon is a dynamic issue in developing new relations which aboriginal self-government will bring among Canadians. It is one resource where native rights have been established as a priority but where sharing with all citizens remains an essential goal.
In both respects, let us resolve to meet the challenge which the salmon symbolizes with care, with sensitivity and with effective management.

Mr. Speaker, the Government of Canada ought to condemn publicly the barbarous action of the United States in returning to its 1981 practice of forcing Haitian boat people refugees to
return to persecution in Haiti. After all, we condemned nations of southeast Asia for the same violations of United Nations law a dozen years ago.
Canada did well to halt deportation to Haiti at the time of the coup last fall, but now we must do more.
There are Haitians in danger of persecution who now have no way to flee persecution in their country, but are not eligible to apply at our Port-au-Prince visa office as refugees because they are in their own country. Therefore, I call on the Minister of Employment and Immigration and the cabinet to use section 62 of the Immigration Act to designate classes of Haitians as being in need of our protection and, therefore, eligible to apply at our visa office for entry to Canada as refugees.

Mr. Speaker, here is some news about the Canadian economy that should be mentioned.
Exports in March reached a record level of $12.8 billion, with $9.8 billion in sales to the United States alone. This is the third month in a row in which we have had an encouraging increase in the gross domestic product.
In fact, exports to the U.S. rose 12 per cent between December and March. During this same period, labour productivity has soared at an annualized rate of 5.7 per cent, surpassing the historic trend in the 1 to 2 per cent range.
Canada is regaining its competitive position. Could it be that our economic policies are beginning to pay dividends?

Mr. Speaker, despite massive public awareness campaigns, drunk driving continues to be a serious problem in Canada.
Recent statistics indicate that the number of impaired driving charges has fallen. Conservative estimates state that the ratio of impaired drivers to the number of those who get caught is 200 to 1.

June 2, 1992
Education has lead to a slight decrease in the problem by reducing alcohol abuse among young people and by diminishing the number of casual drinkers who drive after a few drinks.
We need tougher sentences in court, but the real responsibility lies with each of us. As members of Parliament, we have a special responsibility to lead by example.
During Nepean Days in my riding, a group will be donating proceeds from the sale of Canada Day memorabilia to a local chapter of Students Against Drunk Driving. I applaud their efforts in support of public awareness and encourage other communities to do the same.

Mr. Speaker, following hard on the looting and violence of May 4, yesterday's teenage brawl on Toronto Island is extremely disturbing. This is by no means the first time that incidents of this kind have occurred in Toronto.
At the conclusion of the 1991 Canadian Music Awards, large groups of youths rampaged through the Eaton Centre. Following the 1988 New Year's celebrations in Nathan Phillips Square, gangs of youths smashed windows and looted. In 1987 and again in 1991, youths went on a rampage at the CNE and after the 1981 Grey Cup, football fans celebrated by overturning cars and looting stores.
In fact, there have been riots in Toronto as far back as July 12, 1858 when Orangemen and Catholics fought each other and two men were shot.
That it has happened before, however, is no excuse. This kind of lawless behaviour just cannot be tolerated.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of National Health and Welfare
had responded to constitutional agreements on aboriginal issues by saying, and I quote: "I don't understand that we needed 125 years in Quebec and in two months they, the natives, could get all that they get."
The minister should know the aboriginal peoples have not arrived at this point over a period of two months. It has taken hundreds of years of looking in from the outside. It has taken many years of demanding a place at the table.
What is more, Canadians in every region of this country know this fact and have said they want the constitutional reform package to address these issues.
Stop back-tracking. If Quebec were to separate, it would still have to deal with the same aboriginal issues. Premier Bourassa should come to the negotiating table, because in the long run aboriginal peoples and Quebecers have some common causes. Native self-government will only be a tough sell if you make it so.

Mr. Speaker, members of Parliament, federal departments and the private sector have worked together to make information on potential food allergens available to consumers who are sensitive to certain food substances.
After several private members' initiatives, consumer and corporate affairs developed a requirement for the mandatory listing of ingredients on food labels, an important step in ensuring that consumers are aware of the ingredients in a food product.
I commend the Canadian Food and Food Services Association, the Allergy-Asthma Information Association and the Department of National Health and Welfare for implementing the Allergy Aware Program.
Thanks to this program, quick service restaurants are publishing charts listing the foods served in their establishments and identifying the ten most prevalent allergens consumers may wish to avoid. Such initiatives and partnerships benefit all consumers and must be commended.
June 2, 1992

Mr. Speaker, 60 per cent of the 969 women murdered between 1974 and 1990 in Ontario were killed by male partners, according to the recently released study, "Women Killing: Intimate Femicide in Ontario".
The report shows ironically that shelters created to protect and save the lives of women are also saving the lives of men. The growth in shelters since 1981 correlates to the decrease in the number of men dying at the hands of their female partners. Because women now have somewhere to turn in an abusive situation, they are not resorting to violent means.
Women are still being killed by their male partners in as large numbers as ever. Native women in Ontario are six times as likely as non-native women to be killed by a spouse.
The report notes that the justice system still neglects to protect women. Peace bonds, restraining orders, and other measures have failed and will continue to fail without proper police protocols and appropriate judicial response.
We must continue to support shelters, but the issue of abuse and murder must be brought to light. We must educate all Canadians, particularly the professionals.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance); Parliamentary Secretary to the President of the Treasury Board
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, 75 years ago today, Billy Bishop took off for further glory. He made a one-man raid on a German aerodrome 12 miles behind enemy lines in France. It was a famous raid that was to earn him the Victoria Cross.
Our greatest First World War ace was challenged by four enemy aircraft during the raid. He downed three of them and emptied his gun into the fourth before making his escape.
Billy Bishop was only 24 when he received the Victoria Cross, the Commonwealth's highest award for gallantry, from George V at Buckingham Palace. On the same
occasion, he received the Military Cross and the Distinguished Service Order.
This man from Owen Sound was only one of the many Canadians who brought credit to the Royal Flying Corps and proved to hidebound generals that the new-fangled flying machine had a role in warfare.
Indeed, at the end of the war, over half of the top 20 aces of the Royal Flying Corps were from Canada.
Canadians like Billy Bishop were bom to high skies and open spaces and were ideally suited to the challenges of aerial combat. Let us never forget the skill and the bravery of young men who conquered new frontiers.

Mr. Speaker, an appalling study was released by the Women We Honour Action Committee yesterday. It shows that between 1974 and 1990 at least 61 per cent, and perhaps as many as 78 per cent of the women murdered in Ontario were murdered by the men they had lived with.
It is horrifyingly macabre that in Ontario, and presumably in the rest of Canada, the statistically surest way for a woman to secure her own violent murder is to enter into a spousal relationship.
It says something deeply alarming about the culture of maleness and male violence in our society. It raises frightening questions, the proper answers to which are fundamental to the continued living of up to 100 or more women in Canada this year, next year, the year after that, ad infinitum.
Whatever it takes, and increased funding for women's shelters and post-shelter aid, education of police and the judiciary, and anti-violence education in the schools are utterly essential starting points, this undeclared war against the women Canadian men allegedly love must be ended.

Mr. Speaker, you are well aware of the acute concern that the people of Canada have for their environment. One of the main concerns of Canadians relating to the

June 2, 1992

environment is their own health and the health of their families.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canadians of all ages watch television more than many of my generation would wish. While the use of one's leisure time is a matter of personal choice, the nature of those programs can have a substantial influence on viewers, particularly on the young, and that is of consequence to all of society.
If television portrays life as one in which violence including rape and murder are day-to-day occurrences, young people may learn to accept such violence as being a natural part of their own lives. As an example, 13-year old Virginie Lariviere of St. Polycarpe, Quebec is convinced that her 11-year old sister was brutally and tragically murdered as a direct result of the portrayal of such violence on television.
In a different but equally important vein, Canadians look for television and particularly to the CBC to be an accurate portrayal of the role of our country in world history, but veterans have been outraged and insulted by revisionist portrayals of that history as in the recent series The Valour and the Horror.
Those who produce and those who select television programs have an immense and even frightening influence on their viewing audience, an influence to which they have not given adequate attention.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister. We all hope that the earth summit in Rio will be a success. Already the international community is seriously concerned about the United States' refusal to sign several international agreements which are critical to the success of this summit.
Will the Prime Minister give us the assurance that he is going to pick up the phone and call the President of the United States to urge him to sign these treaties of paramount importance at this time? Otherwise the community of nations will be very disappointed.

Mr. Speaker, I think my hon. friend would take offense if the President of the United States phoned me to tell me to sign a treaty after the Canadian government had decided otherwise. This is something for each nation, for each country to decide for itself.
Of course, on an issue as important as this one, I have already conveyed to the President of the United States our views regarding not only the importance of this summit, but also that of the treaties that flow from it. I
June 2, 1992

stated in a speech yesterday the Canadian position and our objectives for this summit as well as what the Canadian government will do immediately afterwards to contribute to its success, because we believe that this summit is a most important event as regards all issues relating to the development of the environment.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister.
There were supposed to be three conventions at Rio. One was climate change, another was endangered species and the third one was forest management. The convention on forest management has been completely dropped and now the Americans have convinced other industrial nations not to have specific targets or deadlines for the one on climate change.
President Bush's advisers are bragging that when they are back from Rio they will have very little to do to meet any new commitments.
I want to ask the Prime Minister what I asked him in French. Will he use his good office and call the President to tell him that according to what we know, of the three conventions that were proposed, two will not be signed by the United States-one has been in fact dropped- and the third one, the President does not want any deadlines or targets.
Will he tell the President of United States that if that is the case, Rio will be a complete failure?

Mr. Speaker, it is always imprudent to try to judge the results of an important international event before it takes place.
It is always very, very imprudent to suggest that if a given country does not propose or agree to do a certain act, the entire thing will collapse. There are 178 countries in the world. There will be members of the United Nations, there will be more than 110 heads of government at Rio, and while the United States plays an important role in this, as it does in all other international affairs, it is not the only player there.
We do not propose to subcontract our rights or obligations in the environment to the United States or anybody else. We will be there to fulfil our obligations on
Oral Questions
behalf of Parliament and the people of Canada and we expect other nations to do the same thing in their national interest.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Yesterday, while preparing his visit to Rio, the Prime Minister said the environment should be the focus of the next round of the GATT negotiations. If he is really convinced of that, why does he continue to consider the environment as a secondary issue in the negotiations for

Oral Questions
the proposed free trade deal with Mexico? Why does he not insist on the enforcement of common standards for the three countries? Why does he not insist on an accession clause which would protect the environment and on a dispute settlement mechanism which would take the environment into account?

My
friend should be careful when talking about the accession clause because that opens very interesting doors into other areas.
As for the environment, I can assure you that it is part of the Canadian government's negotiating position in all our global initiatives. As I said yesterday in a speech about what would happen after Rio, we intend to make the environment a priority in all our commercial negotiations and particularly in the case of the GATT. Evidently all countries will have to co-operate and participate, but I think Canada is taking leadership action in this area and we will invite others to follow.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister.
The Rio conference is about the environment, trade, and the relationships between the rich and the poor. The North American free trade agreement is about exactly the same thing. The Prime Minister cannot say one thing in Brazil, another in Mexico, and hope to maintain any degree of credibility.
Will the Prime Minister integrate the enforcement of common environmental standards directly into the Mexican agreement and into its dispute settlement mechanism?
The Prime Minister has said that the environment should be the focal point of the next round of GATT negotiations. Will he demonstrate his sincerity now in the current round of Mexican negotiations?

Mr. Speaker, I certainly agree with some of the observations made by my hon. friend. The conference in Rio is going to deal not just with the environment but with the problems of foreign debt, aid and trade in respect of developing nations, how their own economic situations can be accommodated to the horrendous economic costs of preserving their own environment.
There is not a bifurcation but there is an equally important degree of responsibility to be accorded in Rio to the problems of Third World development. I think my hon. friend quite properly points that out.
Canada's policy of eliminating debt in sub-Saharan Africa, our problems of write-offs of debt in the Caribbean countries, the developing countries, are all part and parcel of that general approach.
With regard to trade, we are surprised by some of the opposition we see in this House, because precisely one of the ways that you are going to increase the well-being of people in developing countries, a developing economy such as Mexico, is to enter into a free trade agreement with developing countries, so as to give them access to developed markets. In this way they can enrich their own citizens, thereby raising the well-being of all of their people.
Because of that fundamental principle, and because it has just been articulated so well, I would then conclude that my hon. friend is also speaking, because he is environment and I think associate finance critic, that he is speaking for the Liberal Party and committing them to full support for a North American free trade agreement with Mexico.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister and it concerns the tragic accident at Westray mine.
On May 20, the minister responsible for small businesses assured this House that the government would bring forward and I quote: "all the appropriate information as soon as possible". Two weeks later we still have not received any of that information.
I would like to ask the Prime Minister if he will assure this House that he will bring forward this week all of the documents pertaining to the Westray mine and how those decisions were taken.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to inform my hon. friend that the documents are being assembled and they will be tabled in the House this week.
June 2, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it is very important that they are tabled this week and I thank the minister for his response to that question.
I also would like to ask a supplementary question of the Prime Minister. As we know, there were many concerns prior to the approval of the loan guarantee for the Westray mine by independent consultants, as well as, we understand, by federal departments, about not only the financial viability of the mine, but more importantly, about the safety of the mine.
I would like to ask the Prime Minister, given that he did intervene, as he is asked to do on many projects of regional economic development, could he share with this House the reports on which he based his decision and felt that indeed this was a safe project for the federal government to proceed with.

Mr. Speaker, I indicated to the House yesterday that my involvement in the decision-making process on behalf of projects of regional economic expansion is by and large the same. There is an intervention sometimes by a provincial premier about a given project. It is examined carefully and it follows the cabinet committee route and a decision is made.
We made that decision in Central Nova pursuant to a set of objective criteria and we made a similar decision involving exactly the same company in the constituency of my hon. friend, in the Yukon. That company has provided good employment opportunities there and I think it has been actively supported, quite properly so, by my hon. friend who has made representations on its behalf and to which we responded.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister, of course, is quite right. As I said in my second supplementary, it is to be expected that the Prime Minister of Canada would take an interest in regional economic development opportunities.
Given the very tragic results, however, at the Westray mine it is equally important that the Canadian people are aware that these decisions were taken with full information and knowledge of any risks. There was an environmental assessment done of this project, as we know, from the 1991 Curragh Resources prospectus. It said, and I quote: "The Westray Mine has been reviewed under the environmental assessment and review process".

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, what we hear in this place. It is as if Canadians were not always the same taxpayer.
I have news for the Liberals. Whether you are in northern New Brunswick or in Saskatchewan, when you pay your premium rate you pay it as one Canadian taxpayer.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Labour.
For the past 10 days we have witnessed a labour relations fiasco in Yellowknife. Workers at the giant mine are on strike against their employer Royal Oak Resources. The issues in dispute are the very real health and safety concerns of the workers.
Rather than bargain in good faith and address the concerns of the workers, the company's response to these legitimate concerns for a safe working environment was to hire security guards in riot gear complete with attack dogs.
Will the minister now intervene over and above appointing a mediator to ensure that the company returns to the bargaining table, bargains in good faith and settles not only the strike but also the legitimate health and safety concerns?

Mr. Speaker, I remind my hon. friend that matters of occupational health and safety are under the jurisdiction of the territorial government and not of the federal government. Having said that, the industrial relations part is under the jurisdiction of the federal government.
Last week I was in contact with the owners of the mine and with the union. Having received a request from one of the parties, I appointed a mediator yesterday. The mediator is having the parties meet as we speak this afternoon.
The president of the national union, I understand, has flown to Yellowknife and is meeting with the president of the mine. I deplore the violence that has taken place on the picket lines. I would urge both sides to put their efforts toward settling the disputes.

Mr. Speaker, we are back to the same old thing of pawning off from

one jurisdiction to another the life and safety of workers in these working conditions. That is not acceptable.
Given the violence we have witnessed at the mine, including three workers requiring hospitalization and the constant threat of violence that is ever present due to these wonderful Pinkerton agents-is it not amazing that they keep coming up through history all the time-will the minister now take the next necessary action, amend the Canada Labour Code and introduce anti-scab legislation?

Mr. Speaker, the government has no plans to amend part I of the labour code on industrial relations.
Let me remind my hon. friend that at the federal level in Canada we do settle over 97 per cent of the negotiations of collective agreements without work stoppages. The system works well.
Occasionally we do have cases and that is why we are putting all our efforts into those cases to make sure there is no violence. We want the parties themselves to agree on a settlement.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development.
For many years provisions have existed for development of native self-government agreements on a band-by-band basis in Canada. For example, I understand that the Kingsclear Band, which is one of three in my riding, has achieved considerable progress in many aspects of such a concept, and that the Kingsclear Band is an excellent candidate to become one of the first in Atlantic Canada to sign a self-government agreement.
My question is this: what would such an immediate self-government agreement entail and how would it be implemented?

speakeroldname: Hon. Thomas Siddon (Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development):
speakerposition: Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development
speechtext:
The community self-government policy of the Department of Indian Affairs has been in place, I think at least since 1985. It envisages the negotiation between a particular Indian band or First Nation and the federal government, a set of optional means to be given parliamentary protection by way of legislation, to administer their own communities in the areas of, for example, education and health and lands management and membership, presently covered under the Indian Act.
It is our intention to continue to negotiate such agreements pending an adoption of the inherent right to self-government, should that be constitutionalized in the near future.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Reports from Quebec City show that Arthur Dunkel, the GATT Director General, is stating that our marketing boards must abandon supply management and adopt tariffication. This indicates that the government's message to our associate governments around the world has failed to convince them of the value of supply management.
Will the Prime Minister explain why he thinks his message has not been accepted by presidents Delors and
Oral Questions
Bush, and did he fail because they still remember that Canada's original position was tarification at the GATT until Canada's farmers found out about it?

Mr. Dunkel, who is a hired gun, a bureaucrat, has put forward a text. But individual nations, sovereign nations, will make their decisions in the best interests of their own country and their own economies, how they enter GATT.

I think the hon. minister should remember that for the first two years our position was tariffication. It was changed then.
This past February this House reiterated Canada's support for a strengthened and clarified article XI, 2(c)(1), and urged the Prime Minister to use his influence to build international support beyond that being received from Japan and North Korea. What new support has his activities brought to the supply management cause, and how many countries are now on side with Canada as a result of these activities?
My hon. friend obviously missed the attendance of President Jacques Delors of the European Commission here in Ottawa.
No, I didn't. I was wondering what the results are.

Oh, you were wondering what the results were.

nity from former colonies, and so on, represent important exemptions they are all seeking.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)

Last week several Canadian organizations working with refugees announced that they had given up on the minister of immigration because he had virtually stopped using his discretionary powers to admit refugees on humanitarian and compassionate grounds and consequently their appeals to him were a waste of time.
The law gives the minister the discretion to admit deserving cases when there are humanitarian and compassionate grounds. My question is this: why is the minister refusing to use these legitimate powers and will he make it clear to the Canadian public the criteria he has for using these powers?

speechtext:

The difference between my department and others is that I do not publish every day the individual actions I take in this department on behalf of refugee claimants.
What others? Name the other ministers.
The hon. minister has been asked a question and is on his feet to answer. I ask hon. members to extend the usual courtesy.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is not using these discretionary powers with respect to refugees as they were used in the past and more refugees are now being deported than ever before, often to dangerous situations. For example, last year in Quebec only four cases were accepted on humanitarian grounds out of 884 applications. That is applications to him after they were refused by the board.
June 2, 1992

Will the minister be frank with the Canadian public and say why he has restricted the use of these powers, because he has restricted the use of those powers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, some people can level the charges they want. I know I am entrusted with administering a refugee determination process which the United Nations Commission on Refugees has labelled the best and the fairest system in the world.
Canada welcomes every year and affords protection to tens of thousands of people in need of protection. No other country in the world beats that record. I am applying the law. Every time I receive an intervention on behalf of someone in need of Canada's protection, he gets it.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Prime Minister. Last week in a speech the Prime Minister said:
The road has been dilatory and dangerously indifferent to the
breakup of Yugoslavia.
Today while we meet, Sarajevo is being shelled, thousands of people are being killed and wounded and are losing their homes.

With regard to the procedural argument made earlier today in relation to certain amendments being offered at the report stage of Bill C-81,1 indicated this morning that I would return to the House as soon as possible. I am now ready to share with hon. members the consequences of my consideration of their interventions this morning.

This morning's discussion was about whether Motions Nos. 28, 29,31, 32,33 and 34 standing in the names of the hon. members for Annapolis Valley-Hants, Yorkton- Melville, Churchill, Jonquiere and Papineau-Saint-Mi-chel were in order.

These proposed amendments all seek to change the bill by adding to it specific provisions which would relate to the effect a referendum would have.
The bill as it is now before us and as agreed to by the House at second reading makes no mention of the effect of a referendum. It deals only with the process of holding a referendum. The question of effect is a very vital one of fundamental importance to this country.
The problem faced by the Chair, however, is that proposed amendments are examined, not in relation to their significance, but from a strictly procedurally perspective. Do they seek to alter or amend existing provisions of this bill, in which case they are normally in order and allowed? Or do they seek to import new provisions into the bill which exceed the scope of the bill as already agreed to by the House, in which case they are out of order?
I have examined these particular amendments very carefully and listened attentively to arguments made this morning in the House.

The Chair is bound by quotation 698(1) in the 6th edition of Beauchesne, and I quote:
698. An amendment which is out of order on any of the following
grounds cannot be put from the chair:
Speaker's Ruling
(1)	An amendment is out of order if it is irrelevant to the bill,
beyond its scope or governed by or dependent upon amendments
already negatived.

In considering these proposed amendments and the arguments made, the Chair is of the view that proposed amendments Nos. 28, 29, 31, 32, 33 and 34, in seeking to add to the bill provisions relating to the effect of a referendum, go beyond the scope of the bill as agreed to at second reading.
The bill deals now only with the process of conducting a referendum, and to add provisions relating to the effect of a referendum goes beyond its scope as previously agreed to and is not in order.
The hon. members for Churchill and for Cape Breton-East Richmond both suggested to the House this morning that even if these proposed amendments were to be ruled out of order, the House could decide by consent to consider them anyway and to vote upon them.
That suggestion is absolutely correct. My ruling these amendments out of order does not preclude the House from dealing with them if there is consent. That is a question for the House to decide.
Procedurally, I am bound by the rules and practices of this institution. I must rule proposed amendments Nos. 28, 29, 31, 32, 33 and 34 out of order.
The hon. member for Churchill drew the Chair's particular attention to Motion No. 19, which he agreed was substantially different from the motion which was moved and negatived in committee. On this point, I am persuaded that the member's argument has merit.
Motion No. 19 will therefore be allowed. It will be grouped with Motions Nos. 13, 14, 15, 16, 17 and 18 for debate and voted on only if Motion No. 18 is negatived.
I wish to close by thanking all those hon. members who participated in the procedural discussion this morning for their succinctness and their courtesy.

Mr. Speaker, the eight amendments that are on the table and that are grouped together all refer to the same objective, namely to put a ceiling on expenses during a referendum, as well as to set up a referendum committee for the yes side and one for the no side, which we call umbrella committees.
In our democracy and in our country we have a Charter of Rights and Freedoms which contains various provisions. Two of those provisions are invoked depending on the group of people who want to achieve a specific objective. Some people ask us this question: Based on the freedom of expression and the freedom of association, can we force people to be grouped together under a committee for the yes or no side during a referendum? On the other hand, section 1 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and of the Constitutional Act of 1982 says: "The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society."
In Quebec we have already had a referendum in 1980. At the time, there was a referendum committee for the yes side and a one for the no side, in which the principles of equity regarding expenses related to the referendum were complied with. Today, in 1992, at a time when our country is possibly getting ready for a national referendum, I am motivated by the same kind of spirit, a desire for equity and the need for both sides to have access to the same means. In that context, I feel that it would be appropriate to include in this bill very strict rules to ensure that the yes side and the no side can potentially get the same public funding to promote their respective views. It is in that context that I tabled these amendments to the bill, which my colleagues from the Bloc Quebecois as well as all the members of this House were informed of more than 10 days ago. I tabled these amendments in order to ensure fairness. Generally speaking, the moneys available for the yes and the no sides regarding referendum expenses would be the same across the country, as well as in each province and constituency.
I would like to mention a newspaper article dated May 20, in which Minister Marc-Yvan Cote was reported as saying the following: "Under our system, there must be a minimum of fair play between the two opposing camps. Referendum legislation must reflect this attitude, said Minister Cote." The article went on to say: "While recognizing the federal government's right to conduct a referendum, Mr. Cote referred to an unconscionable free-for-all in which anyone could spend $20,000, as a slap in the face of democracy."
Our government does restrict what a registered committee or group of persons may spend to 56.4 cents per voter. However, there are no restrictions on the number of committees that may be set up across the country. There could be 10, 20, 100, 1,000, or tens of thousands. Nobody knows. As a result, we could end up with an entirely inequitable situation in our democratic system. That is why I tabled the amendments that are before the
House today, which our colleagues will be asked to discuss and possibly vote on later.
I have no desire to prolong the debate. I think the gist of what I wanted to say is there. My colleagues will be able to consider the kind of ceiling I wanted to introduce in the bill to achieve a certain degree of fairness.

At this point, Mr. Speaker, I think it would be useful to refer to a tried and true democratic tradition. The Canada Elections Act has from the very beginning of its existence provided that it was imperative in an election for the parties to be subject to the same spending limits. Why? Because choosing those who govern us is so important, the consequences are so far reaching, we must ensure the electorate makes its decision in a context devoid of any brainwashing, where serious debate can take place and where it is possible to make an objective decision.

In other words, when important decisions are to be made in a democracy, money should not be the deciding factor. We want the citizens of the country to decide. That is the most elementary and essential principle of how democracy operates, a principle that has been recognized and applied in the Canadian democratic system.
One wonders why, when the stakes are much higher than in the case of electing a government, the House of Commons should decide to depart from a long tradition of democracy in this country and proceed to destroy the equality and balance that exists between the opposing parties?
On what grounds would the Canadian legislator depart from a tradition that has made our democratic system one to be proud of?
The only argument I heard was the existence of the Canadian charter. It is a strange paradox that a charter that was supposedly put in place to protect freedom of expression, maintain civil rights and prevent unfairness is now invoked to prevent legislators from maintaining a democratic tradition that would preserve fairness between the parties in an essential debate on the future of Quebec and Canada.
We must believe that this argument is invalid. We must have at least enough respect for the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms to say it does not stand for such unfairness, that it would not force legislators to act unfairly or in a discriminatory fashion. Quite the contrary.
If legislators had to take a risk on the chance that opponents of the bill would challenge it in court, they should err on the side of freedom of expression; they should take a risk for fairness and balance between the sides.
I submit that regardless of antagonisms, because I know there are some, and regardless of bitterness, because of course there is bitterness, but only out of respect for this long unbroken democratic tradition in Canada of which Quebec is a part and which Quebec will want to follow if it becomes sovereign, because we believe in Canadian democracy; we respect it and it is one of the great values that we recognize in our country.
Why, when we want to rebuild the country, when we want to give people a chance to speak out on a basic issue
Government Orders
concerning its existence, its fundamental rights, why would we break with the principle of fairness with respect to spending?
I did not hear a single demonstration or justification from the government that would lead us to believe that this principle should now be set aside. It is true when I say that Quebec has experience with it, because Quebec had a charter of rights too in 1980, when the government held a referendum with spending limits and yes and no committees. Anyone could have used the Quebec charter to prevent the government from holding a referendum which allegedly violated freedom of expression. That did not happen because basically, we well know that the best way to violate freedom of expression is to swing the balance, deprive one of the parties in the debate of financial resources and give them all to the other side.
I believe that we legislators should ensure that the people decide and to the extent that this referendum seeks to let the people speak and not the political establishments, and not get around public opinion in an important debate, to the extent that the people's voice is to be heard, we should ensure that the big corporations, the banks, high finance and fundraisers do not sway the decision on the side of money. Just out of respect for the referendum principle, which would refer the matter to the people, let us trust them and ensure that they can decide freely and fairly.
I cannot understand that in a Parliament where legislation has been debated for 125 years in order to defend democracy and protect democratic rights that are always threatened, we are today pleading against a government that would have us believe that for the sake of freedom of expression, it has to limit that freedom and trample it under foot.
We are not demanding anything subversive. We are asking for rules of fairness that respect democracy, so that people can speak freely. On that, we fully support the efforts made by the hon. member for Jonquiere. We may differ, but we believe that he is right on that and we hope that many voices will be raised on both sides of the House and more and more among the Conservatives to uphold freedom.
Second, regarding these two committes, the bill allows a multiplicity of committees. It seems to limit the number of committees since the expenses are limited for

What a pitiful sight these thousands of committees created all over Canada without a clear mission in the absence of two distinct kinds of committee, the yes committees and the no committees. Mr. Speaker, I cannot miss this opportunity to look at the motions tabled by the member for Jonquiere and to tell him that I also believe this to be a fundamental aspect of the democratic value of this potential exercise.
