Obviously the only way to have a fair referendum is by establishing two sides. Right now, there could be hundreds if not thousands of committees on all sides. One can imagine the free-for-all that this situation could trigger. Just think that any small group in the country could decide to form its own committee. Any businessman could set up his own committee. There could be a Paul Desmarais committee and a Guy Saint-Pierre committee. In the end, every businessman will want to have his own committee.
In reality, this would make no sense. I hope the government realizes that if it does not adopt civilized rules, nobody will take this exercise seriously. There is even one of my colleagues who would recommend a committee for the former colleague of the member for Jonquiere, Mr. Gravel, and a Michel Cogger committee. There could be an unlimited number of committees and all kinds of them. Obviously, nobody would take such an exercise seriously. Therefore, if the government wants to make a fool of itself, it simply has to keep going in that direction.
The beauty of the referendum legislation in Quebec is that all those who participated in this democratic exercise recognized its fairness. The reality is that the sovereignist government lost its referendum but it recognized the democratic value of the result that same day. Everybody accepted the rules of the game. And that is what was extraordinary in the end. I am not commenting on the result but on the democratic process. In fact, at that time, I also thought that the result was extraordinary. But what I must tell you, Mr. Speaker, is that all the participants in this exercise agreed it was a fair and equitable process.
Here, the government started off on the wrong foot. There is nobody in this Parliament, except the leader of the government and a few other ones who want to use this issue for political expediency rather than for sound motives, and we can see that people do not take this exercise seriously. Even the Liberal Party leader, who had himself suggested the idea of a referendum, was forced to admit that the rules established under this bill are undemocratic. I was surprised to hear, for example, that even if the bill was undemocratic, he was still willing to vote for it. That worried me a little during the press conference. I know that the hon. member for Jonquiere made similar remarks, so I wonder how elastic his conscience is.
When we talk, for example, of the Quebec referendum bill and the principles that guided it: first, the umbrella committees, and second, the spending limits, it is obvious that in a democracy, with Canadian democratic values, we agreed that in order to get elected here in the House of Commons, we could not let people spend millions and millions of dollars. We did not want to accept the American jungle where everybody has to-campaigns are so expensive that we become the victims of various
June 2, 1992

lobbies. We must virtually submit ourselves to the power of money.
This Parliament gave itself some rules and each of us who sits here recognized the value of spending limits. Why is it that, with such a fundamental issue as the Constitution, it would now be the free-for-all? There is something indecent about all this. It is so indecent, so blatant, that it is staring you in the face. That is why the citizens, particularly from Quebec, will never feel bound by the result of a process which is distorted from the beginning. If the government thinks it can solve anything with such a trivial process, it is grossly mistaken.
As soon as there is a free-for-all in the establishment of the committees, as soon as the power of money overrides the content of the debate and the decision of the citizens, it is obvious that there is absolutely no fair play. We are in the heart of the British institution which should be the perfect example of fair play. I know some days you doubt it, Mr. Speaker, but I also know you are trying every day to apply that fair play.
I tell you there is no fair play in this bill. All political parties, except the Conservatives, who have their eyes completely blindfolded, recognize that there are problems with the democratic value of that exercise. Why not solve at least that detail?
The hon. member for Jonquiere has the merit of at least raising the issue. I must also tell you that it is obvious that the financing criteria-I did not have time to thoroughly examine the proposal from the hon. member for Jonquiere-I do not know if he limited the contribution to individual financing or if he allowed large corporations a free hand. I suppose that with its slogan that almost says "Let the people decide", the government would want to make sure that the decision would be taken by the citizens, and not by the multinationals. It is obvious that a decision by the citizens should be financed and managed by the citizens themselves.
I would like to return to the attack in order to emphasize a point. A bill that is flawed from the beginning, such a weird exercise will get no credibility in the eyes of the public, particularly in Quebec considering the precedent and the democratic values that are essential to that exercise.
Government Orders
I cannot imagine the government thinks for a minute that anybody in Quebec could feel bound by such legislation. I cannot understand why English Canada does not object to that. I cannot understand why Conservative ministers and members from English Canada are willing to accept such unworthy legislation. They should oppose it, they who claim to be the great protectors of democracy. The most stupid argument I heard was from the Government House Leader, who used the excuse of the charter of rights to violate those same rights.
You must have quite a bit of imagination to think that Canadians and Quebecers are going to swallow the argument that the Canadian charter of rights prevents us from putting some democratic principles into this referendum bill.
This is insulting for the charter of rights. In 1980, all parties involved accepted the results. The problem in 1980 was not a weakness in the statute, it was a weakness in the Constitution. Her Majesty was not bound by the statute. In other words the spending limits applied only to Quebec citizens. The federal state was not bound by a provincial statute, which means, unfortunately, it was able to abuse the system. Everybody now recognizes this was the only weakness of the process in 1980.
Consequently, I congratulate the hon. member for Jonquiere, I am looking forward to testing the depth of his convictions and I hope he will stand up to the end.
Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, members of the Bloc Quebecois do not have to decide for me what I will do on third reading.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: That is not a point of order, it is a point of debate.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, these amendments are very important and I want to speak generally in favour of the initiative taken by my colleague and friend, the member for Jonquiere, in bringing this group of amendments, which the Speaker has clustered together. There are eight different motions that we are looking at together.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
It is important to understand that there are three main elements to this package of amendments. The first element is that it recognizes the importance of having committees, or as some call them, umbrella committees, to organize the activity for the yes side and the no side in a national plebiscite.
The second element is that there would be spending limits that would maintain an over-all balance and fairness in the process so that spending does not become the name of the game, but that the whole effort is proceeded with on a balanced footing.
The third element in this group of amendments by my colleague is to deal with some reasonable exceptions. This is done by accommodating the exception that is already in the bill as drafted by the government, an amount of $5,000. This is to ensure fairness and balance for the rigorously independent of mind.
Briefly, it is important at this juncture of the debate to note the origins of each of these three elements of the package; the umbrella committees, the spending limits and the reasonable exceptions. The first concept of having the umbrella committees is something that interestingly enough was developed in the United Kingdom for its plebiscite in 1975 on whether the U.K. should continue to adhere to the European Community.
I know that a great many Canadians think that holding direct votes, referendums and plebiscites is something that is unparliamentary and not in our best British parliamentary traditions. It is a sobering thing though to actually look and see that it was the British who developed this concept in 1975.
It worked well enough there to attract a positive interest of legislators in our country and in the province of Quebec. The National Assembly embraced this concept in La Loi sur les referendums and has seen it used not only in the direct vote on May 20, 1980 on the question of sovereignty association, but also one time since the charter has been in force. It was used in the October 1989 vote in northern Quebec on the whole question of the forming of a new constitutional system of government for the aboriginal people, the Inuit of northern Quebec.
There has twice been the experience in our country with umbrella committees, both of them in the province of Quebec. Quebec has again given our country leadership, not only on this issue, but on how to have modem structures that permit the necessary balance.
On the second area, the spending limits, the origins are equally important for all of us as we consider these amendments because it was the Barbeau commission that reported in 1966 on spending laws for Canadian federal elections, election expenses and so on. That report, like a great many commission reports in this country, languished for not just months but years until it was picked up by a Liberal member of Parliament who was quite interested in the subject, Mr. Hyliard G. Chappell. He got a committee going and all of that initiative led to the Barbeau commission's report coming forward in 1974 when Parliament passed the Election Finances Reform Act in 1974.
Since then we have had a couple of decades of experience at the national level with rales that govern how money is raised and spent in the conduct of our national elections. The effort here is to see those same principles and the values that underlie them carried into this legislation that will pertain to a national plebiscite on constitutional matters.
Those rules from 1974 had one feature that was very significant and that was where Parliament decided to draw the line between freedom of expression on the one hand and the efficacy of these election finance laws on the other. As long as we are a country there will be debate over where that line should be. There is clearly a trade-off here. The issue of having that line in the right place so that there can still be adequate freedom of expression but also respect for these rules that Parliament wants so that our political processes do not simply become a process dominated by the wealthy is the fundamental issue.
When Parliament passed, very rapidly, amendments in 1983 to shift that line dramatically in favour of the finance laws and against freedom of expression, that put in place a law that was certainly challengeable. It was challenged by the National Citizens Coalition. In Alberta that case came before the Court of Queen's Bench and, interestingly enough, the National Citizens Coalition, an organization that is often denigrated by many in
June 2, 1992

the country, was found to have led an important fight there. Subsequently, many others who often speak up for civil liberties in Canada, freedom of expression and so on, were latecomers to climb on board that bandwagon. It was very important that that issue was before the courts and that was a decision in Alberta that struck down the place that Parliament had put that line because it too greatly infringed on freedom of expression.
Perhaps the government of the day should have challenged that law, should have appealed that decision, but it did not and the fact is that right now we have that same issue here before us in the House of Commons in this bill. It is the content of the amendments by the member for Jonquiere. Regardless of whether the member for Brant thinks that it should have been appealed- I agree, it should have been-the fact is it was not. At least Parliament, better than the Supreme Court of Canada in my view on this matter, is now going to have a chance to consider again where that line should be on freedom of expression.
That is why I think the third point about reasonable exceptions is the point that raises the role of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the Supreme Court of Canada in relation to Parliament and what we do here.
I am glad that the approach taken by the member with his amendments dovetails with what is already in the government's bill where there is exception made, as I say up to $5,000, for those who want to operate outside the two umbrella committees.
Let us be careful. I would caution those in government who try to draft legislation before they bring it to us here to be careful, to not be so anxious to have legislation that is charter proof that it becomes plebiscite proof. We will end up with something that could never be challenged in court because it has nothing left in it to be challenged but it does not have either any of the substance, rules, and procedures necessary to see the plebiscite will be fairly carried out in accordance with the values that for 20 years have become deeply enshrined in our Canadian political culture.
Government Orders
In short, it is important in speaking to support these amendments to make these two final points. Talking about umbrella committees is not to talk about strait-jackets. The creation of umbrella organizations, under which the many different groups would maintain their integrity and positions could operate, is quite different than something that would unduly restrict them as a strait-jacket would.
The view that they would have to be the exclusive vehicles for those supporting or opposing has been an unfortunate attitude with which to view the umbrella committees. They can operate to advantage to bring structure, purpose, and channelling the energies of those who want to divide up the broadcasting time, who want to raise and spend the moneys, but they do not have to cut it off entirely. That is the reason these amendments deserve support.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on a point of order, an agreement could not be reached under the provisions of Standing Orders 78(1) or 78(2) with respect to an allocation of time for report stage and third reading of Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums on the Constitution of Canada.
Under the provisions of Standing Order 78(3), I give notice of my intention to move a time allocation motion at the next sitting of the House for the purpose of allocating a specific number of days or hours for the consideration and disposal of proceedings at the said stages.

Mr. Speaker, I want to say a few words here in support of the motions before us calling upon the government to consider forming umbrella committees in order to conduct the referendum campaign in a more orderly way.
I realize there are certain problems with umbrella committees. There are legal opinions. There may be violations of the charter under section 2(b), which is the freedom of expression section, or section 2(d), the freedom of association section. That is not known for sure and legal opinions on this are divided.
We have had many legal opinions saying that exclusive umbrella committees are probably a violation of the charter. Other people have said if we have certain reasonable limitations in terms of spending they may not be violations of the charter.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
The suggestion I made before and I want to make again to the government is a quick reference to the Supreme Court so we can clarify this particular issue. This issue will go to court anyway in this country very shortly. There is going to be a court action launched in the province of Quebec to challenge the Quebec referendum law under freedom of association and under freedom of speech in that particular province. There will be a court judgment rendered on whether this is in violation of the charter.
I suggest the government consider at this time referring this issue to the Supreme Court and try to get the Supreme Court to fast-track it so we can get a decision on whether we can establish umbrella committees.
The province of Quebec is recommending the use of the notwithstanding clause to make this charter proof. I certainly would not recommend that action at this time for this House but that is one possibility of what could be done.
If we can set up umbrella committees, that is the way the House should go. In a referendum question, a referendum bill, as seen before the House today, we will have one question, maybe two or maybe three.
I think one option is to set up a yes committee for each question and a no committee for each question. People who are on one side or the other can be part of that committee like they were in the province of Quebec.
It worked very well in the province of Quebec in 1980 in terms of how it was organized. I was part of that in terms of the federal New Democratic Party on the no side. I was the person who was delegated by my party to attend some of the no meetings.

I remember when the hon. member for Hull-Aylmer was also a member of the no committee in 1980 in the province of Quebec. He was mayor of Hull at the time, if I remember correctly. He was there, and I was there as a federal delegate for the New Democratic Party.

We had no problem in terms of the organization of the no committee or the yes committee in terms of allocation of time for advertising, or allocation of time in terms
of money. It was orderly. It was very well done. We did not have any problems in terms of the organization.
If it is the will of Parliament, if it is the will of the people of this country that we set up an umbrella committee again, surely we can argue before the court that would be seen as a reasonable limitation on freedom of association or expression in this country.
After all, in a referendum question there are only two answers. It is either yes or no. It is not maybe or maybe but. It is yes or no. If everybody is on the yes side or the no side, surely to goodness you can get together and organize, as in the province of Quebec, fair treatment of all the organizations in each umbrella group and make the argument before the court that is not unfair limitation under section 2(d) of the charter which is freedom of association.
In terms of freedom of speech, another suggestion I have made in terms of the motion before the House here today is perhaps if people do not want to be part of these umbrella committees, we can take an idea from the Lortie royal commission on electoral expense in which he said that if you do not want to belong to a political party, you will be allowed to spend $1,000 as an individual in terms of third-party advertising.
You, Mr. Speaker, are supposedly not part of the yes side or the no side of this referendum. You could if you were a private individual spend $1,000 in buying ads, printing brochures, renting halls and persuading people to vote either yes or no. Therefore, you do have an outlet in terms of political expression and I wish the government would take a serious look at that as one of the options.
Also in terms of freedom of speech in this country and freedom of expression, all we are talking about here is the freedom of paid expression. No matter how we organize this, people can still write letters to the editor, phone the open-line shows, knock on doors to persuade their neighbours and talk to their neighbours. They can still participate in public meetings.
There is no inhibition in terms of their freedom of speech, and that is a very basic part of this country as well. The freedom of speech is there. All we are talking about here is the freedom of paid speech in this country. We could construct rules and regulations that are charter
June 2, 1992

proof if we had national umbrella committees in this country, one for the yes and one for the no.
If we have more than one question on the referendum, we could have an umbrella committee for the yes and for the no for the first question. We could have an umbrella committee for the yes and for the no for the second question or, if there are three questions, have the same thing for the third question as well.
Again, there is a parallel here with the Elections Act. There is no limitation in this country on the number of political parties. What we have in this country is a limitation of what each political party can spend but there is no limitation on the number of political parties.
If we had two, three, four, five referendum questions, there would be a limitation on the umbrella questions in terms of the number of questions that were asked, but the limitation would be the number of committees in so far as we have the number of questions.
There is a parallel here to the Elections Act. Before I sit down, I ask that the parliamentary secretary across the way take a serious look at this proposal.
I know the member for Etobicoke-Lakeshore has made many recommendations as a recognized expert in this House on referenda as to how we could have a yes and no committee, how they could be charter-proof, how people can guard and keep their right for freedom of speech and freedom of opinion, freedom of association being given respect in this country and still have an orderly referendum campaign where there are reasonable spending limitations so that people on both sides of the question have the same access to the paid media.
In the final analysis, what we have to make sure we do is that we have a fair piece of referendum legislation, where a referendum cannot be bought or be perceived to be bought by one side or the other.
If there is a perception that somebody is buying the referendum, somebody has access to all kinds of money that the other side does not have, it can create a backlash in this country, a backlash in one of the regions of the country, in the province of Quebec, in western Canada, in Newfoundland, or anywhere else. We can find that
Government Orders
people are voting against the perception that big money is buying the result, rather than voting for or against the question in the referendum itself.
Those are some of the basic arguments as to why, if there is to be a national referendum, we have to have spending limitations. The only way we can have real spending limitations is if we have umbrella committees. It was done in the province of Quebec. It was suggested by the member across the way from Etobicoke-Lake-shore, suggested by the Liberal Party, supported by our party and suggested by our party in terms of the committee. The government itself has said in principle it would like to have limitations on what could be spent.
Let us be a little bit imaginative with all the legal advice we have in this country and draft legislation where we can have yes and no committees for every question. We would still have freedom of speech for third party advertising, if that is what they call it. I would say $1,000 limitation per person and have a referendum campaign in this country that is fair and just.
I want to stop here and just ask the parliamentary secretary to go back to the government to see whether or not there is a possibility of taking another look at it, a different way of organizing this, so we can have meaningful limitations.
In the final analysis, if we have legislation that is perceived not to be fair it could come back to haunt all of us. We do not want that.
What most of us want in this House is a constitutional package in the end that is supported by the three national political parties, all the provincial governments and the aboriginal people. Then if we have a national referendum, a package that the people of this country will feel good about going out and saying yes to, we will all be on the same side in saying yes to Canada and saying yes to this new federation.
Now we have a bill that is drafted in such a way where certain organizations can spend an awful lot of money. If we are not careful, we run the risk of souring the atmosphere and having people vote against a reasonable package when they otherwise would not do it.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext:
Order, please.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
It is my duty, pursuant to Standing Order 38, to inform the House that the questions to be raised tonight at the time of adjournment are as follows: the hon. member for Winnipeg North-Revenue Canada; the hon. member for Edmonton East-The Environment; the hon. member for London East-Housing; the hon. member for Okanagan-Shuswap-Atmospheric Contaminants; the hon. member for Notre-Dame-de-Grace-Immigration and Refugee Board.

Mr. Speaker, I just want to take a few minutes to support the motion moved by the hon. member for Jonquiere. I find it totally acceptable, and all my colleagues in the Bloc Quebecois agree.
I know very well the 1980 legislation Quebec used to hold its referendum. As my colleague from Yorkton- Melville mentioned earlier, I was mayor of Hull in 1980. The no umbrella committee asked me to chair the western Quebec committee and demand a renewed federalism from the federal government.
At the time, I thought it was still possible for us to get along in this country. I chaired the no committee in the Outaouais region, and in that referendum, the no side won with 59.8 or 59.9 per cent of the votes. The PQ government, which initiated the referendum legislation, bowed to the will of the people and accepted the results of the referendum, and from then on we waited for the renewed federalism we had been promised. I know all about it.
On April 20, 1980, I stood on the same platform with Brian Mulroney, Jean Chretien and Claude Ryan, at the Robert-Guertin arena in Hull, in the riding of Hull- Aylmer. At the time, this was 12 years ago, we were fighting for renewed federalism.
Today, 12 years later, we are discussing ways to put Quebec in its place, right here in Ottawa, in the Parliament of Canada.
The Conservative member for Jonquiere tabled a motion that is very similar to Quebec's referendum legislation, which reflects a respect for democracy. It respects both the yes and the no sides. There is a balance between the yes and no umbrella organizations, and there are specific spending limits within those organizations. We call that fair play. We call that democracy. We call that respect for the other side.
Today the government has decided to practically ignore the motions tabled in this House. Only two members of the Conservative Party bothered to speak to the motion tabled by the hon. member for Jonquiere, and the leader of the government has already moved a motion of closure for tomorrow. Yesterday those members said: we will not give the 48 hours provided under the Standing Orders, and we will move closure to end debate after 24 hours. Today, another motion for closure.
I think this kind of interference is unfortunate. I think it is sad to see democracy flouted this way, especially when we are dealing with the Constitution of the country, a Constitution foundering on the distrust of two founding peoples, a Constitution they want to ram down the throats of Quebecers. They want to put Quebec in its place.
Mr. Speaker, I joined the Bloc Quebecois in this House after June 23, 1990, when Meech Lake lost any significance it may have had and was turned down by two Canadian provinces. I did so to defend the greater interests of Quebec within the precincts of the House of Commons and to serve the interests of Quebec, with the respect owed to democracy and the integrity we can expect from our elected representatives.
I think it is a great pity that a Conservative member would put forward today amendments relating to the very substance of democracy and the freedom of expression and that this government refuses to be tolerant, and moreover ignores it.
As for the fact mentioned when Bill C-81 was tabled that a ceiling could not be put on expenditures because this could be challenged under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, this raises serious doubts about the confidence placed in the charter. If we do not have confidence in it, let us change it or repeal it. Why not have used the notwithstanding clause? If that had been the case, it would have been possible to use the clause to maintain democracy, to maintain expenditures for such a major consultation process, as Quebec will be consulting its people at the same time on its political future, under a

yes umbrella and a no umbrella, in face of the constitutional rejection of English Canada.
Are you suggesting that this House force down the throat of Quebecers a deal bought through a massive publicity drive, at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars, such as the one this government has already embarked upon? That is absolutely incredible. It is unthinkable.
People in my riding were telling me just the other day that they could not even watch a simple game of hockey on TV without an advertisement on what a beautiful country Canada is being flashed on the screen every five minutes. It is not ads such as those that will bring unity between the two founding nations. That is not the point. It is much more a matter of Quebecers mistrusting English Canadians who cannot even agree among themselves.
Mr. Bourassa cannot be blamed for not attending the federal-provincial conference, when the nine Englishspeaking provinces do not agree among themselves. How do you expect Quebec to reach an agreement on its own?
We will support the motion of the member for Jonquiere. For those who are watching us on TV today, especially in Quebec-I can understand where English Canada is coming from-I think it is a great pity to have such an undemocratic piece of legislation forced on them. Unfortunately, we can find only a few members to stand up for Quebec in this House, including the hon. member for Jonquiere who supported it and proposed amendments. The others caved in, and are grovelling. They will be remembered in history-not that of Canada, but the Quebec history-as members sent to Ottawa to defend the interests of Quebec and caved in on such a fundamental issue. I urge Conservative and Liberal members from Quebec to prevent this from becoming a reality.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to intervene in this debate to support the motions presented by the hon. member for Jonquiere.
I want to congratulate him on presenting Motions Nos. 2, 7, 35, 50, 51, 54, 55 and 59, which in many respects take some provisions of the Quebec Referendum Act that advocate not only the creation of two umbrella commit-
Govemment Orders
tees, one for the yes side and the other for the no, but that set limits on what each of these two committees can spend in a referendum campaign.
Of course, the Liberal Party of Canada hopes a Canadian referendum will not only give Canadians a chance to express their opinion on thorough changes to their Constitution but also give them a chance to say yes to Quebec and give Quebecers a chance to say yes to Canada. We are not afraid of such a public consultation. The Bloc Quebecois representatives seem to fear like the plague a referendum in which Quebecers would be asked their opinion on a series of constitutional amendments in line with the traditional five demands of the Quebec government headed by Robert Bourassa.
We think that the Government of Canada and the provinces are moving towards a compromise on a package of constitutional proposals that could considerably change our Canadian system, but that could also satisfy Quebec's legitimate aspirations. What better way than to ask them directly, in a referendum, whether or not they approve of this constitutional package put forward by the Government of Canada and the provinces. I think that is a completely democratic exercise which is quite legitimate and in no way contravenes the basic rules of democracy.
Certainly it would be better to bring all the yes supporters together on one side and all the no supporters together on the other and to impose strict spending limits on them. That is the purpose of the amendments proposed by the hon. member for Jonquiere. I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, that the members of the Liberal Party of Canada will support these amendments enthusiastically.
We hope that the government will think it over and see that these amendments are justified. If, unfortunately, the government did not accept these amendments, we would at least hope to see a government representative, either the parliamentary secretary today or even better the Prime Minister himself on third reading, assure us that if the government holds a referendum on specific constitutional offers, it will not abuse its spending power and intervene in a heavy-handed, undemocratic way. Then both the supporters and the opponents of this proposal can fight it out on a level playing field with equal chances for both sides.

June 2, 1992
Government Orders
It seems obvious to me that it is not necessary-as I have already said in this House-to spend excessively to point out the merits of Canadian federalism. I do not think that it is necessary to spend excessively in any province of Canada, including Quebec. I am convinced that it is not necessary to use money to convince Quebecers of the merits of a good constitutional reform that would provide a favourable response to the five traditional requests of the Government of Quebec.
This is why I regret that, so far, the government has not deemed appropriate to impose more rigid limits to electoral and referendum expenses, and more importantly, does not see the opportunity to copy the referendum legislation of Quebec.
Some of our colleagues in this House ask themselves this question: if the amendments tabled by the member for Jonquiere were to be rejected, should the member for Jonquiere or other members in this House who support these amendments vote against the referendum act?
Mr. Speaker, I must tell you that at this time we hope these amendments will be agreed to. We also hope the government will recognize that it is essential to have a bill that will not only be fair but will be perceived as being fair and equitable for everybody, including the separatists, the independantistes and the members of the Bloc Quebecois. It seems certain to me that whatever we do, those independantistes, separatists and members of the Bloc Quebecois will always be disappointed and unsatisfied, but I nevertheless think the referendum legislation is essential for the Government of Canada.
We believe that if the Government of Quebec has an act that enables it to hold a referendum, and if the government of British Columbia has an act that enables it to do the same, it goes without saying that the Government of Canada should also have a piece of legislation enabling it to hold a referendum and to consult Canadians across the country or in specific regions of Canada.
I do not know what this government will do following the constitutional negotiations. I do not know if the Government of Canada will invoke section 3 of this bill
to hold a Canadian referendum in some provinces but not in all of them. This means that the Government of Canada could, provided it reaches an agreement with the provinces, allow those interested in doing so, to hold their own referendum according to their provincial legislation. The Government of Canada could therefore hold a referendum in the provinces where there would be no desire to hold such consultation at the provincial level. It is quite possible that all these discussions which seem to scare the members of the Bloc Quebecois are totally useless. Indeed, it may well be that, under this legislation, there will be a referendum in several provinces, but that in the case of Quebec it will be its referendum act that will apply. Should this be the case, all the antics and fears of our friends from the Bloc Quebecois will have been useless and unnecessary.
Whatever the situation may be, I will end by saying that we must have a referendum act that enables the Government of Canada to act if it deems appropriate to do so. Also, this legislation must, as much as possible, ensure a level playing field for the two sides, and be democratic by allowing those who want to belong to either group to be subjected to the same rules and be allowed roughly the same electoral and referendum expenses.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened very carefully to the comments made by my friend from Jonquiere, a Quebecois patriot, who nevertheless works hard for a renewed Canada.
My friend was a member of the two special joint committees and he was present at the organizational meeting of the legislative committee on that bill.

He is a member of Parliament who has truly made a constructive contribution to this debate and to many preceding debates. He has presented a series of amendments which would have the effect of bringing into Bill C-81 the concept of exclusive umbrella committees as in the Quebec legislation on referendums. Only two umbrella committees would be set up: one in support and one in opposition to the question or questions.
June 2, 1992

The mechanics for the administration of this scheme would be left to the Governor in Council to make by regulation. There are numerous issues raised by this approach, issues which were also canvassed in the legislative committee which completed its work last Tuesday.
The first of these would be the restriction of participation to two exclusive committees and that, as has been touched on in this debate, raises charter concerns with respect to freedom of expression and to freedom of association.
I heard my colleague from Lac-Saint-Jean seeking to deprecate the importance of that. I wonder if he was perhaps speaking in the context of the 1980 situation which preceded the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. I know he referred to the Quebec charter, but I do not think it is exactly four-square with the situation we have here.
My friend from Papineau-Saint-Michel referred to the charter issue only very fleetingly. That, in the opinion of this House, the government should ban the importation of all hazardous waste.
She said: Mr. Speaker, I am glad to have the opportunity to speak on this timely issue on the eve of a conference which could have overwhelming implications for the future of our planet.
The motion I am introducing is a very simple motion but it flows from the work done by the Brundtland commission dealing with our common future and the work that will be examined in great detail at the conference in Rio de Janeiro. I would like to read the motion into the record:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should ban the
importation of all hazardous waste.
It is a simple motion but it speaks to the issue which has gripped our nation and indeed the world for the last number of years and that is the issue of what constitutes sustainable development.
One of the messages from the Brundtland commission was clear: think globally and act locally. This particular motion enshrines the notion of local action into parliamentary law. What it says is in future industrial development and in future residential development in our country we have to be prepared to deal with our own hazardous wastes at home and likewise that other countries must feel compelled to do the same.
It is an important concept because in the world of garbage in which we live, and Canada is one of the greatest garbage-producing nations in the world, it is critical that we not only find ways of disposing of our garbage, but begin to take responsibility for our own waste. This particular motion enshrines that as a principle, specifically in dealing with the issue of hazardous waste.

I first introduced this motion in 1989 when we learned that Canada was importing BPC contaminated gasoline. At that time, customers had no idea that the gasoline and heating oil they were purchasing might be toxic. Farmers did not suspect that the oil used to heat their greenhouses might be toxic. I tabled the motion hurriedly in order to ban the importation of hazardous waste into Canada and to make Canadians understand that we should treat our own BPCs. It is not enough to encourage BPC exports. It is absolutely essential also that we have the means to dispose of our own waste. I had this matter slated for debate in early May last year because I knew that the situation not only had not improved but had worsened.
It is a fact that Canada remains, on the eve of the Rio de Janeiro meeting, the single largest producer of waste material in the world. Canada is the most wasteful country in the world. On the other hand, we have yet to adopt a policy requiring that, as a matter of principle, we
June 2, 1992

Private Members' Business
treat our own waste material and especially our toxic waste.
In fact the situation keeps worsening even now. In its May 27 issue, La Presse reported that Canada is the world's largest importer of toxic waste material.

We are the largest world importer of toxic waste. Canada, a country that wants to be a world leader in Rio, is also the world leader in importing toxic waste.

It reported that 95 per cent of all hazardous waste material imported into Canada comes from the United-States. Canada imports 142,000 tons of dangerous waste, and exports almost as much.
So we have nearly 300,000 tons of hazardous waste crossing the border between Canada and the United States.

Think of it, 300,000 tonnes of toxic waste is passing our border on an annual basis. Small wonder that the fire-fighters of Canada are doing their level best to get legislation which would ensure that transportation of toxic waste be properly computerized. In that amount of tonnage, clearly there is the possibility for some very serious accidents and very serious public ramifications.

Canada is the biggest carrier of toxic waste. As luck would have it, I am raising this issue at the very moment the international community is meeting in Rio to try to find answers to the major ecological problems of this planet.

It is just a coincidence that this motion is coming forward on the week that we are moving into the real conference but it is also critical that as Canadians, before we preach to the world, before the Prime Minister unveils another empty green plan, we should tell the world we are the number one world importer of toxic waste, a fact that most Canadians are not aware of.

I hope conference delegates in Rio are not aware of these statistics because it would be very embarrassing for Canada. It is embarrassing to rank first as a carrier of toxic waste when we want to tell the Third World it should clean up its act.
There is plenty to do here. In fact, there is a whole industry that depends on toxic waste for its very existence. There is a company north of Montreal that advertises in the United States, saying that it assumes full responsibility for waste upon reception.
This goes against the principle that producers should be responsible for their own waste.

That violates a basic principle that those who produce waste should be responsible for its disposition.

There are now more than 1,000 sites where toxic waste can be found in Canada. More than 50 of these sites are orphan sites, which means no one is responsible for them.

Fifty orphan sites, 1,000 toxic sites across this country, and 50 of those that nobody is taking responsibility for. They are simply washing their hands.

In Quebec there are 333 depots for toxic waste. [English]
Three hundred and thirty-three depots for toxic waste, 66 of them are dangerous for health.

It would cost $500 million to clean them up. While we are arguing here in the House about what should be included in the referendum bill, we have a situation where we already have 333 hazardous waste depots in Quebec alone, and we would need $8 billion to clean up the 1,000 contaminated sites we have across Canada.

It would take $8 billion just to clean them up.

This year, 6.5 million tons of hazardous waste will be produced.

Six and a half million tons of toxic waste will be produced in this country in this year alone.

As long as people think they can get rid of their toxic waste by exporting it abroad, they will continue to produce it.

The point is, as long as we have the option of sending our waste elsewhere and developing an international traffic in toxic waste, it becomes very easy not to deal with the issue of waste. Stick it on a barge, send the PCBs off to a Third World country. As long as we fail to enshrine the notion of looking after our own waste, we will not have any initiative locally to actually deal with our own toxic waste.
The practice of Canada-U.S. trading of toxic waste encourages waste production.
Indeed, an entire industry depends on importing toxic waste to make a profit. Banning the importation and obviously the export of hazardous waste would force us as Canadians to deal with our own waste. The surest way to responsible management is to deal with it ourselves. As long as we can ship it off to another country, the tendency is to look the other way, to take the easy route.
In our own country we have some startlingly positive examples of companies that have done something to reduce their own waste and with stupendous results. At one office, an Etobicoke office, Bell Canada implemented a comprehensive program of waste reduction. Before the program, the building was generating 800 kilograms of waste a day; coffee cups, paper, beverage cans, packaging and organic wastes. Through education and provision of creative alternatives, those 1,000 employees at the Etobicoke office have managed to reduce the waste from 800 kilos to 22 kilos a day. That is hardly enough to fill three green garbage bags.
That is a 97 per cent reduction. They are so excited about this program that Bell intends to extend its program to all 110 buildings in Ontario and 85 buildings in Quebec with positive results.
Another company, Canadian Waste Exchange, specializes as an intermediary between car manufacturers, for example with extra paint, and schools which can use that material. There are other dramatic radical ways of eliminating waste. Quaker Oats Company has introduced an innovative way of looking at packaging. Nonmarketable food because of faulty packaging or expiry dates instead of being thrown out is now recycled and used as chicken feed.
In 1986, the company began the process of recycling food that had not been used. It saved $1 million in the process and it has invested that money in a closed loop water cooling system, totally eliminating all discharge into a nearby river.
Dupont has decided to eliminate the production of virtually all hazardous waste by 1995 by substituting non-toxic products, for example, toxic products like arsenic. It is also changing its production technology.
Dupont is also committed to reducing junk waste by at least 50 per cent before the end of this decade. It is finding that reduction pays great dividends. Reducing waste by 38 per cent in the production of paint at Dupont has meant an increase of one-third in productivity.
This is what sustainable development is all about. Being environmentally responsible also makes economic sense. Instead of being the laughing stock of the world by being the largest trader in toxic waste as we speak, Canada could become a world leader by accepting full responsibility for the waste that we generate. The examples I have just mentioned show that it makes economic sense.
Surely there are some necessary adjustments and some investment costs in the short term but those will pay off in the long term economically and environmentally.

Canadians are concerned about the quality of the environment and about the effect of pollution on their health. We do not want to be the toxic waste dump site of other countries.
June 2, 1992



Mr. Speaker, we do not want to be the world's toxic garbage dump.

They do not want our industries to keep producing waste that is a threat to the health of their children, their parents and their own health. We no longer want to ship our waste to our neighbours. Banning imports and exports of toxic waste would force companies to reuse, recycle, reduce and, in the long run, eliminate the production of toxic products.
If Canada does not act now, other countries will take the lead and Canada will remain behind, its procedures and technologies getting obsolete.
The demand for environmentally friendly technologies and industrial processes will give rise to a great innovative creativity. It will create new markets and jobs and it will allow companies not only to conserve resources but also to reduce costs and increase profits. Japan already has understood the enormous possibilities and so have certain European countries.
In 1990, Japan launched a 100-year plan,

sto lat, as they say in Polish, a 100 year plan has been launched in Japan.

They will convert entirely to sustainable development and invest enormous sums of money in research in order to develop clean technologies.
During the seventies and eighties, Japan seized the opportunity of the oil crisis to change its production methods. Already it uses only 50 per cent of the physical resources and energy required by the United States and by Canada to create one unit of production.

The Japanese understood early that small cars not only make economic sense, they make environmental sense. Right now they have taken the approach to energy use that sees very specifically that for every unit of production created in Japan, they use only 50 per cent of the energy that we use in Canada and the United States. Why? Because they are operating in a much smaller geographic area. They understand that what we do to the land comes back to haunt us in the food chain in the
Private Members' Business
Great Lakes, in the tainting of mother's milk that we see now in the Arctic and in the fact that the food chain in the Great Lakes has already seen evidence of potential brain damage as a result of toxic waste disposal.

Only if we adopt a long-term vision and if we have the courage to act shall we succeed in saving our planet.

In the United States the House of Representatives in Congress is looking at legislation to ban the export of hazardous waste and the import into the United States. The representative who introduced the motion said: "Banning exports supports and goes beyond the international agreements we have signed at Basel in 1989. It also represents good foreign policy".
As we know trans-boundary movement of hazardous waste is controlled by the Basel convention signed in 1989. Yes, Canada is a signatory and the Basel convention was created in response to concerns that hazardous wastes were being dumped on developing countries, particularly the African states, in a non-environmentally responsible manner. In other words developed countries were using the undeveloped countries as their cheap dumping grounds.
The underlying objectives of the Basel convention were to cut down waste, to recycle waste and to make sure that where possible home country responsibility prevailed for waste disposal and treatment.
However, African countries at that convention understood that the only effective solution was to ban outright the importation of waste on their continent.
It is important that we in Canada also take our own world responsibility seriously and we show the nations of the world, as they gather in Rio de Janeiro, that we too care about this issue, understand this issue and have the political will to act on this matter.
This House can, by way of this motion, unequivocally affirm our will to implement a real policy aimed at setting Canada on the path of world leadership and sustainable development. It is not enough to go to Rio and make fancy declarations to the international media. We have got to back it up with actions. This particular motion makes it clear that Canada will follow the objectives of our common future in thinking globally and acting locally. That is the direction in which we have to go-
